§ 34.15  SICK LEAVE.



   (A)   Each full-time employee shall be entitled for each completed
month of service to sick leave of ten hours with pay.  Unused sick leave
shall be cumulative up to 960 hours, unless more than 960 hours are approved
by the City Manager.



   (B)   Incentive pay for unused sick leave. Permanent, full-time
employees of the village who have accumulated a sick leave balance of 90 days
(720 hours) shall be compensated annually for 33.3% of the number of hours in
excess earned, not to exceed 15 days (120 hours) each year times the hourly
rate of base pay in effect at the time such payment is made. The actual
payment to the employee in any one year shall not exceed 40 hours of pay. 
The remaining unused sick leave, not to exceed ten days (80 hours) per year,
shall be accumulated with the original 90-day balance to a maximum allowable
sick leave balance of 120 days (960 hours).  The number of benefit hours
shall be based upon a 12-month reporting period of December 1 through
November 30.  Payment shall be made during the first week of December in
each year.



   (C)   Payment for accrued sick leave upon retirement.  Any employee
retiring from village service will be paid one half of his accrued sick leave
up to a maximum payment of 480 hours.



   (D)   Transfer of sick leave accumulated from employment with
another Ohio public agency.  Any employee who has prior service with another
Ohio public agency may transfer any unused and/or uncashed sick leave
balance, up to a maximum of 960 hours, to the village. It shall be the
responsibility of the employee to provide satisfactory documentation
substantiating the uncashed sick leave being transferred from his or her
prior employer. Any such sick leave accumulated while employed by another
Ohio public agency shall, upon exhaustion of sick leave accumulated while
employed by the village, be available for use by the employee under the
applicable sick leave use provisions contained in the personnel policies.
Transferred sick leave shall not be eligible for compensation under either
the annual incentive pay program specified under Incentive Pay For Unused
Sick Leave or the retirement compensation specified under Payment for Accrued
Sick Leave Upon Retirement. The maximum combined usable balance of village
accumulated and transferred sick leave that can carry over for future use
shall not exceed 960 hours on December 1 of any year.



('80 Code, § 35.03(C)) (Ord. 30-77, passed 12-19-77; Am. Ord. 19-90, passed
12-17-90; Am. Ord. 21-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 25-95, passed 12-18-95;
Am. Ord. 12-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 12-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord.
17-03, passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 30-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 14-05,
passed 12-12-05;  Am. Ord. 23-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 18-07, passed

§ 34.16  FUNERAL LEAVE.



   (A)   An employee shall be paid for two working days of funeral
leave in the event of the death of a relative in his or her immediate family
defined as follows: spouse, child, brother, sister, parents or legal
guardian, grandparents, mother-in-law or father-in-law.  Such day must
coincide with the day of death or day of the funeral, unless otherwise
approved by the Chief of Police or unless the day of death or day of the
funeral occurs on employee's regularly scheduled day off then such days must
be contiguous to the regularly scheduled days off.  Any leave under this
section shall be paid by the city and shall not be charged against any leave
balance accrued by the employee.



   (B)   In the event of a death of a relative other than those in the
immediate family as described above, the Police Chief may, at his or her sole
discretion, grant one day of funeral leave so the employee may attend the
funeral.



   (C)   In circumstances of unusual distances of travel or extreme
weather conditions the Police Chief may, at his or her sole discretion, grant
up to two days of leave with pay for the employee to travel to the funeral of
a relative in the immediate family.



(Ord. 21-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 25-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
12-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 22-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 17-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 30-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 14-05, passed
12-12-05;  Am. Ord. 23-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 18-07, passed 12-17-07;

12-18-17)



§ 34.17  PERSONAL TIME OFF.



   (A)   Full-time employees of the Police Department shall be
permitted to take eight hours off per year as personal time off, subject to
the advance approval of the Chief of Police.  Employees must work at least
six months during their first calendar year of employment in order to be
eligible to take the allotted personal time off during that year.



   (B)   Full-time employees of the Police Department shall accrue one
additional personal eight hour period off per year upon the first day of any
calendar year following their respective fifth, tenth, fifteenth, twentieth
and twenty-fifth anniversaries marking uninterrupted service with the
village, subject to the advance approval of the Chief of Police.



   (C)   Permanent employees of the Police Department shall be eligible
for up to three additional incentive based personal days off each year. One
such additional day will be provided for any employee who does not use any
sick time for the 12 month period preceding December 1 of any calendar year.
The second such incentive personal day will be provided to employees in each
department which, in the judgment of the City Manager, achieves or exceeds
preset departmental goals and objectives for the 12 month period preceding
December 1 of any calendar year. The third such incentive personal day will
be provided to employees who, in the judgment of the City Manager, achieve or
exceed preset health and/or wellness goals for the 12-month period preceding
December 1 of any calendar year. The incentive personal days earned shall be
credited to the personal leave balance of the affected employees on December
1 of each calendar year and must be used before June 1 of the following year.



   (D)   Unless otherwise specified in this section, personal days off
must be taken during the year in which they accrue. With the exception of
incentive personal days off, employees may not carry unused personal days
forward to the next calendar year.



(Ord. 21-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 25-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
12-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 22-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 17-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 30-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 14-05, passed
12-12-05;  Am. Ord. 23-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 18-07, passed 12-17-07;
Am. Ord. 07-10, passed 12-15-10; Am. Ord. 14-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.

12-18-17)



§ 34.18  HEALTH CARE INSURANCE OPTION.



   (A)   Employees of the Police Department, who have health care
insurance through the employer of a spouse, may elect not to participate in
the health care insurance program offered by the village.  Upon satisfactory
proof of adequate coverage through the spouse's employer, the City Manager
may authorize the payment of a $4,000 incentive to employees opting out of
full family coverage.  The election of this option may be made during the
first week of the first month of the health insurance plan year. Payment of
the incentive shall be made with the first pay period following the election
of this option.



   (B)   In the event that an employee's spouse loses health care
coverage, and the employee or spouse/family is accepted back into the village
health care insurance program, the employee shall be responsible for
reimbursing the village on a pro rata basis for previously paid incentive.



   (C)   This health care insurance option shall not be available to
otherwise eligible employees when the spouse is also an employee of the
village and the spouse's alternative health care insurance coverage is also
provided by the village.



(Ord. 21-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 25-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
12-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 22-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 17-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 30-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 14-05, passed
12-12-05;  Am. Ord. 23-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 18-07, passed 12-17-07;

12-18-17)



§ 34.19  TERMINATION BENEFITS.



   Employees who retire from the Police Department in good standing are
eligible to receive termination benefits as set forth in § 35.65 and in the
Personnel Policies contained in the General Orders of the Police Department.
Retiring employees are only eligible to receive such termination benefits one
time.



(Ord. 30-04, passed 12-20-04; Ord. 14-05, passed 12-12-05;  Am. Ord. 23-06,
passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 18-07, passed 12-17-07; Am. Ord. 07-10, passed

§ 34.20  INJURY LEAVE.



   (A)   An employee who suffers an on the job injury while in the
performance of his or her official duties and acting within the scope of his
or her employment with the village, who is not working as a result of that
injury, will be compensated at his or her regular rate of pay at the time of
the injury less the employee's income from any other source including
Worker's Compensation, retirement, or other forms of government payment, for
a period of time not to exceed 180 calendar days, except with the approval of
City Council.  The village shall have the right to demand proof of all items
listed above regarding receipt of payment from other sources.  Falsification
of any information with respect to this or any paid leave may be grounds for
discharge.



   (B)   An employee claiming the right to receive, or who is
receiving, injury leave compensation, may be required by the village, from
time to time, to submit to a medical examination by a physician selected by
the village for the purpose of determining any questions regarding
eligibility for and duration of injury leave.



   (C)   An employee on injury leave and unable to perform his or her
regularly assigned duties may, at the discretion of the village, be assigned
other duties not requiring great physical exertion in lieu of injury leave
compensation, provided such work is available and either the employee's or
the village's physician releases the employee to return to work under such
conditions.  If the village's and employee's physicians disagree as to the
return to work issue such physicians shall mutually select a third physician
to decide that issue.  The third physician shall be chosen from among those
providing service covered by the employee's health insurance plan.



(Ord. 07-10, passed 12-15-10; Am. Ord. 14-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.
08-13, passed 12-16-13; Am. Ord. 09-14, passed 12-15-14; Am. Ord. 10-15,
passed 12-14-15; Am. Ord. 09-16, passed 12-12-16; Am. Ord. 14-17, passed
12-18-17)



§ 34.21  WORKER'S COMPENSATION.



   No employee may receive payment from the village for sickness or injury
if he is receiving Worker's Compensation for the same purpose.  Therefore,
once a Worker's Compensation claim has been approved the Worker's
Compensation checks will be signed by the employee and turned over to the
village.  The village shall continue to pay the employee his/her regular
paycheck during this period of time.



(Ord. 07-10, passed 12-15-10; Am. Ord. 14-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.
08-13, passed 12-16-13; Am. Ord. 09-14, passed 12-15-14; Am. Ord. 10-15,
passed 12-14-15; Am. Ord. 09-16, passed 12-12-16; Am. Ord. 14-17, passed
12-18-17)



§ 34.22  EMPLOYEE MERIT PROGRAM.



   (A)   There is hereby established an employee merit based program.
The purpose of this program is to provide an annual budget appropriation to
the City Manager to be used to award those full-time, non- contract employees
who have demonstrated exemplary service highlighted through the successful
completion of a specific project, task or accomplishment which exemplifies
the village mission and departmental goals. Annual appropriations to this
program are not guaranteed.



   (B)   Any merit awarded by the City Manager shall not be based upon
hourly compensation at time and one-half nor shall exempt employees lose
their exempt status by participating in the program. The amount and timing of
merit solely shall be within the discretion of the City Manager through
recommendations from department heads. The employees who are eligible for the
program shall be determined at the discretion of the City Manager.



   (C)   The amount of any merit and the employees who shall receive
such merit may vary from year to year. Any merit awarded shall not increase
the employee’s base salary in the determination of annual compensation nor
shall the failure to award merit or the award of a lesser amount from year to
year considered as disciplinary action or as a decrease in performance.



(Ord. 14-17, passed 12-18-17)



HEALTH STANDARDS AND MEDICAL EXAMINATIONS



§ 34.25  AUTHORITY OF MANAGER.



   The City Manager is authorized and directed to cause the rules and
regulations in §§ 34.26 through 34.30 to be in effect for the Police
Department of the village. 



('80 Code, § 35.05) (Ord. 4-51, passed 3-27-51)



§ 34.26  MEDICAL EXAMINATION MUST ACCOMPANY APPLICATION.



   Every applicant for position as a member of the Police Department shall
be in good health and shall furnish, with his written application otherwise
required, such evidence of a recent medical examination and of good health as
may be required by the City Manager.  The City Manager may require, in
addition to the foregoing, such other medical examinations by a physician of
the City Manager's choosing and the results of such examinations shall be
available in all respects to the City Manager.



('80 Code, § 35.06) (Ord. 4-51, passed 3-27-51)



§ 34.27  GENERAL GUIDE TO MANAGER IN RECRUITING POLICE OFFICERS.



   (A)   General.  Applicants for recruit positions shall be not over
30 years of age.



   (B)   Height and weight.



      (1)   Measurements should conform to the following schedule at
the time of the physical examination (candidate will be stripped at the time
of the measurement):



   Height               Minimum   Maximum
         weight.      weight.



   5 ft. 8  in.   140 lbs.   180 lbs.



   5 ft. 9  in.   145 lbs.   185 lbs.



   5 ft. 10 in.   150 lbs.   90 lbs.



   5 ft. 11 in.   155 lbs.   195 lbs.



   6 ft. 0 in.   160 lbs.   200 lbs.



   6 ft. 1  in.   165 lbs.   205 lbs.



   6 ft. 2  in.   170 lbs.   210 lbs.



   6 ft. 3  in.   175 lbs.   215 lbs.



   6 ft. 4  in.   180 lbs.   220 lbs.



   6 ft. 5  in.   185 lbs.   225 lbs.



   6 ft. 6  in.   190 lbs.   230 lbs.



      (2)   Police recruit applicants who are less than 5 ft. 9 in.,
145 lbs., may be rejected.  Any applicant over 6 ft. 6 in. or 230 lbs. may
be rejected.  The examining physician is authorized to reject any applicant
who in his opinion is overweight for his build even though he might weigh
less than the maximum shown above.



   (C)   General appearance.  The applicant should  be free from any
marked deformity, from all parasitic or systemic skin disease, and from
evidence of intemperance in the use of any or drugs. The body should be well
proportioned, of good muscular development, and show careful attention to
personal cleanliness.  Marked tendency toward obesity, muscular weakness, or
poor physique should cause rejection.  Girth of abdomen may not be more than
the measurement of chest at rest.



   (D)   Nose, mouth, and teeth.  Obstruction to free breathing in
either nostril, chronic catarrh, or very offensive breath, should cause
rejection.  The mouth must be free from deformities or conditions that
interfere with distinct speech or that predispose to disease or hypertrophy
of tonsil or thyroid enlargement.  Teeth must be clean, well cared for, and
free from multiple cavities.  Missing teeth may be supplied by crown or
bridge work; where site of teeth makes this impossible, dentures will be
accepted.  Pyorrhea should cause rejection.  Thirty-day period for
correction of dental defects may be permitted by examiner.



   (E)   Hernia.  Actual or potential hernia in any form should cause
rejection.



   (F)   Genitalia.  Must be free from deformities and from marked
varicocele, hydrocele, enlargement of the testicle, stricture or incontinence
of urine.  Retained testicles or atrophy should cause rejection.  All
venereal diseases of those organs should cause rejection.



   (G)   Rectal.  Simple hemorrhoids may be accepted by the examining
physician, but marked hemorrhoids, or fistula-in-ano, should cause
rejection.  History of findings of severe chronic constipation should cause
rejection.



   (H)   Spinal.  Simple asymptomatic pilonidal sinus may be accepted
by the examining physician, but obvious or suspicious pilonidal lesion or
fisseurs should cause rejection.  Spinal curvature should cause rejection.



   (I)   Arms and legs, hands and feet.  Should be free from
affections of the joints, sprains, stiffness, or other conditions, such as
flat feet, ingrowing nails or hammertoes, which would prevent the proper and
easy performance of duty.  First (index), second (middle), and third (ring)
fingers and thumbs should be present in their entirety.  Great toe should be
present in its entirety.



   (J)   Eyes.  Color blindness, loss of either eye, chronic
inflammation of the lids, strabismus, or permanent abnormalities of either
eye should cause rejection.  Less than 20/20 in best eye and 20/30 in worst
eye, as determined at the time of physical examination by tests prescribed by
the commission, without glasses, should cause rejection.  Depth perception
and fusion must be normal.



   (K)   Ears.  Normal hearing with each ear is required.  Chronic
recurrent running ear should cause rejection.



   (L)   Respiration.  Should be full, easy and regular; the
respiratory murmur should be clear and distinct over both lungs, and no
disease of the respiratory organ be present.  Lungs will be x- rayed.



   (M)   Circulation.  The action of the heart should be uniform, free
from organic changes.  Blood and pulse pressures should be approved by
examining physician.  Maximum acceptable blood pressure, 150 systolic, 90
diastolic.  History of findings of anemia and severe blood dyscrasia should
cause rejection.  Tendency toward varicose veins should cause rejection.



   (N)   Internal.  History of findings of gall bladder disease,
peptic ulcer, chronic appendicitis, mucous colitis, dysentery or malignancy
should cause rejection.  Kidneys should be healthy and urine normal.



   (O)   Nervous system.  History or findings of mental disorder,
severe nervousness, insanity, unstable nervous system or sensory or motor
changes that would interfere with performance of duty should cause
rejection. 



('80 Code, § 35.07) (Ord. 4-51, passed 3-27-51)



§ 34.28  CONTINUOUS EXAMINATIONS OF POLICE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS REQUIRED.



   (A)   Members of the police department under 36 years shall submit
to a medical examination by a physician of Council's choosing every three
years and the examination shall be paid for by the village.



   (B)   Members of the police department between 35 and 40 years of
age shall submit to a medical examination by a physician of Council's
choosing every two years and the examination shall be paid for by the village.



   (C)   Members of the police department over 40 years of age shall
submit to a medical examination by a doctor of Council's choosing every year
and the examination shall be paid for by the village.



('80 Code, § 35.08) (Ord. 4-51, passed 3-27-51)



§ 34.29  SPECIAL EXAMINATIONS.



   In the event the prognosis of any medical examination referred to in
§§ 34.25 through 34.28 suggests a member's inability to serve as a member
of the police department with full effectiveness, the member shall do
everything necessary to clear up the deficiencies by such means as may be
prescribed by competent medical advice.  Any such member may be required to
take special examinations over and above the examinations required by §§
34.25 through 34.28 as in the opinion of the City Manager may fit the need of
any particular member's health condition.



('80 Code, § 35.09) (Ord. 4-51, passed 3-27-51)



§ 34.30  LIMITED DUTY OR DISCHARGE.



   In the event any member's health or physical condition is such as to
render him unable to perform his duties as a member of the department with
full effectiveness and there is no other position open to him in the
department which, having in mind his physical condition and health, will
enable him to be an effective member of the department, the City Manager may
take action as he may deem best. However, members presently employed by the
department shall in each case be given special consideration in view of the
fact that no physical examination was required at the time he became employed
as a member of the department.  The City Manager shall at all times
cooperate with the police relief and pension trustees of the village with
respect to limited duty or discharge of members who fail to have physical
condition and health sufficient to permit the member's full and effective
service as a member of the department. 



('80 Code, § 35.10) (Ord. 4-51, passed 3-27-51)



   RETIREMENT



§ 34.40  RETIREMENT TIME.



   A member of the police department of the village shall retire from
service at such time as either of the following events occurs:



   (A)   At such time as the member reaches 58 years of age, or;



   (B)   At such time as the member by virtue of years of service with
the police department of the village and prior service with the Ohio State
Highway Patrol or the police or fire department of a municipal corporation or
township in Ohio, could have, if he had elected to comply with the provisions
of R.C. § 742.38 et seq., whether or not the member did in fact comply,
accumulated the maximum pension benefits in the police and fireman's
disability fund.



('80 Code, § 35.15) (Ord. 21-75, passed 6-23-75)



Cross-reference:



   Payment for accrued sick leave upon retirement, see § 34.15



   Contributions to police and fireman's disability and pension fund to be
"picked up" by village, see § 35.43



   Supplemental retirement plan to include police department employees,
see § 35.73



§ 34.41  CONTINUOUS SERVICE BEYOND RETIREMENT.



   Notwithstanding § 34.40, if the City Manager in consultation with the
chief of police determines that any member of the police department of the
village, who has otherwise reached the time for retirement as set forth in §
34.40, is still fully able to continue to perform his duties in a manner
consistent with the high standards demanded of a member of the police
department the City Manager may provide that the member may be continued on
as a member of the police department on a year to year basis under the same
terms and conditions of employment as any other member who has not reached
the age of 58 years.  However, no member of the police department of the
village shall be continued on as a member of the police department after he
shall have reached the age of 65 years. 



('80 Code, § 35.16) (Ord. 21-75, passed 6-23-75)

REGULATIONS FOR PUBLIC WORKS AND WATER WORKS DEPARTMENT EMPLOYEES



§ 35.10  COMPENSATION.



   (A)   The rates of compensation for the employees of the Public
Works and Water Works  Department of the village are hereby adopted
according to ordinance, and shall be payable bi-weekly. Upon recommendation
of the Superintendent of the Public Works and Water Works Departments and
approval of the City Manager, the rate of pay of each member of the Public
Works and Water Works Department may be set within the classification and
limits herein fixed, and subject to a step increase plan set by the City
Manager. Seasonal student, part- time service workers and part- time GIS
technician shall not be entitled to any other village benefits provided under
this subchapter.



   (B)   Unless otherwise specified in this subchapter, the personnel
regulations for non- uniformed employees of the Public Works and Water Works
Department, as amended to the effective date of this subchapter, shall govern
further details of salary administration and working conditions of hourly
paid employees.



   (C)   With respect to employees who are compensated on an hourly
basis, all hours worked in excess of 40 hours in any one week or over eight
or ten hours per shift (depending on how shifts are assigned shall be
compensated for at time and one- half rate in accordance with F.L.S.A.
regulations.  The eight or ten hour overtime provision shall not apply to
training time assigned or approved by the employer.



   (D)   The positions of Public Works/Water Works Superintendent,
Administrative Assistant, Clerk Secretary and other part-time or seasonal
positions, shall be exempt from the Merit System Ordinance of 1970.



   (E)   Employees of the Water Works Department scheduled to carry an
off duty pager as part of their on-call status as first responders related to
emergency water system repairs will be compensated with $100 per week for any
weeks during which they are assigned to such status. Employees assigned to
this rotation will be



required to respond by telephone in no more than ten minutes and, if needed,
be on the scene no more than 60 minutes after receiving notification of a
problem.



   (F)   Employees of the Public Works Department scheduled to carry an
off duty “Pager” or “Phone” as part of their on-call status as first
responders related to emergencies will be compensated with $100 per week for
any weeks during which they are assigned to such status. Employees assigned
to this rotation will be required to respond by telephone in no more than ten
minutes and, if needed, be on the scene no more than 60 minutes after
receiving notification of a problem.



   (G)   An employee may be required to wear a pager/phone at times
designated by the employer. An employee required to wear a phone/pager shall
be paid $15 for each overnight period during which the employee is required
to wear and respond to the pager/phone.

§ 35.11  ANNUAL LONGEVITY PAYMENT.



   (A)   Permanent, full-time employees of the village, with at least
five years of continuous service to the village, shall receive an annual
longevity payment in addition to their regular compensation in accordance
with the following schedule:



YEARS OF SERVICE   PAYMENT



5 through 9 years      $900



10 through 14 years      1,000



15 through 19 years      1,100



20 through 24 years      1,200



25 or more years      1,350



   (B)   The longevity payment will be made annually during the first
week in December to those qualified employees of record, who have or will
have completed the specified number of years of service on or before December
31 of that year.



   (C)   In case of death, retirement or resignation, longevity pay
will be prorated based on the number of completed months actually worked
during the calendar year and paid as part of the terminal benefit lump sum.

25.



   (B)   In addition, the above hourly employees in the Public

of pay for emergency call-ins on recognized holidays during the 24-hour
duration of the holiday.

§ 35.13  SICK LEAVE.



   Each employee shall be entitled for each completed month of service to
sick leave of one and one-quarter days with pay.  Unused sick leave shall be
cumulative up to 120 days, unless more than 120 days are approved by the City
Manager.



   (A)   Incentive pay for unused sick leave. Permanent, full-time
employees of the village who have accumulated a sick leave balance of 90 days
(720 hours) shall be compensated annually for 33.3% of the number of hours in
excess earned, not to exceed 15 days (120 hours) each year times the hourly
rate of base pay in effect at the time such payment is made.  The actual
payment to the employee in any one year shall not exceed 40 hours of pay. 
The remaining unused sick leave, not to exceed ten days (80 hours) per year,
shall be accumulated with the original 90-day balance to a maximum allowable
sick leave balance of 120 days (960 hours).  The number of benefit hours
shall be based upon a 12-month reporting period of December 1 through
November 30.  Payment shall be made during the first week of December in
each year.



   (B)   Payment for accrued sick leave upon retirement.  Any employee
retiring from village service will be paid one-half of his accrued sick leave
up to a maximum payment of 60 days pay.



   (C)   Transfer of sick leave accumulated from employment with
another Ohio public agency.  Any employee who has prior service with another
Ohio public agency may transfer any unused and/or uncashed sick leave
balance, up to a maximum of 960 hours, to the village. It shall be the
responsibility of the employee to provide satisfactory documentation
substantiating the uncashed sick leave being transferred from his or her
prior employer. Any such sick leave accumulated while employed by another
Ohio public agency shall, upon exhaustion of sick leave accumulated while
employed by the village, be available for use by the employee under the
applicable sick leave use provisions contained in the personnel policies.
Transferred sick leave shall not be eligible for compensation under either
the annual incentive pay program specified under Incentive Pay For Unused
Sick Leave or the retirement compensation specified under Payment for Accrued
Sick Leave Upon Retirement. The maximum combined usable balance of village
accumulated and transferred sick leave that can carry over for future use
shall not exceed 960 hours on December 1 of any year.



(Ord. 20-90, passed 12-17-90; Am. Ord. 22-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord.
26-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord. 13-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 23-99,
passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 18-03, passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 31-04, passed
12-20-04; Am. Ord. 15-05, passed 12-12-05; Am. Ord. 24-06, passed 12-18-06;
Am. Ord. 19-07, passed 12-17-07; Am. Ord. 08-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord.

12-12-16; Am. Ord. 13-17, passed 12-18-17)



§ 35.14  VACATION LEAVE.



   (A)   Vacation leave applicable to employees hired prior to January
1, 2003.



      (1)   Full-time employees covered by this subchapter who were
hired prior to January 1, 2003 shall be entitled to two calendar weeks (ten
work days) of vacation with full pay after service of one year, including
prior service with other governmental units in Ohio.



      (2)   Employees having five or more years of service,
including prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled,
during each year thereafter, to three calendar weeks (15 work days) of
vacation leave with full pay.



      (3)   Employees having 20 or more years of service, including
prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled, during
each year thereafter, to four calendar weeks (20 work days) of vacation leave
with full pay.



      (4)   Employees who do not use all of their annual vacation
before the end of the current year may carry over up to one-half of their
annual vacation leave entitlement to the following year. In no event shall
the amount of vacation leave that is carried-over to a subsequent year exceed
one-half of the employee's annual entitlement.



   (B)   Vacation leave applicable to employees hired after January 1,
2003.



      (1)   Full-time employees covered by this subchapter who begin
employment after January 1, 2003 shall be entitled to accrue 3.077 hours of
vacation per pay period, or two calendar weeks (ten work days) of vacation
leave annually, including prior service with other governmental units in Ohio.



      (2)   Employees having five or more years of service,
including prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled,
during each year thereafter, to accrue 4.615 hours of vacation per pay
period, or three calendar weeks (15 work days) of vacation leave annually,
with full pay.



      (3)   Employees having 20 or more years of service, including
prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled, during
each year thereafter, to accrue 6.154 hours of vacation per pay period, or
four calendar weeks (20 workdays) of vacation leave annually, with full pay.



      (4)   In no event shall the amount of vacation leave that is
carried on the village vacation accrual records exceed 150% of the employee's
annual entitlement.



(Ord. 22-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 26-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
13-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 23-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 18-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 31-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 15-05, passed
12-12-05; Am. Ord. 24-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 19-07, passed 12-17-07;
Am. Ord. 08-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 15-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.

12-18-17)



§ 35.15  FUNERAL LEAVE.



   Permanent, full-time employees of the village shall be permitted to
take two days off, without credit to vacation or sick leave, for the purpose
of attending the funeral of a family member. At the discretion of the City
Manager, this leave may be extended to a maximum of three days for the
funeral of a relative where the employee may be required to be responsible
for arrangements or travel long distances.



(Ord. 22-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 26-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
13-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 23-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 18-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 31-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 15-05, passed
12-12-05; Am. Ord. 24-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 19-07, passed 12-17-07;
Am. Ord. 08-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 15-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.
09-13, passed 12-16-13; Am. Ord. 10-14, passed 12-15-14; Am. Ord. 11-15,
passed 12-14-15; Am. Ord. 08-16, passed 12-12-16; Am. Ord. 13-17, passed
12-18-17)



§ 35.16  PERSONAL TIME OFF.



   (A)   Full-time employees of the Public Works and Water Works
Department shall be permitted to take one work day (8 hours) off per year
with pay as personal time off, subject to the advance approval of the
Superintendent.  Employees must work at least six months during their first
calendar year of employment in order to be eligible to take a personal day
during that year.



   (B)   Permanent employees shall accrue one additional personal day
off per year upon the first day of any calendar year following their
respective fifth, tenth, fifteenth, twentieth and twenty-fifth anniversaries
marking uninterrupted service with the village, subject to the advance
approval of the Public Works/Water Works Superintendent.



   (C)   Permanent employees shall be eligible for up to three
additional incentive based personal days off each year. One such additional
day (8 hours) will be provided for any employee who does not use any sick
time for the 12 month period preceding December 1 of any calendar year. The
second such incentive personal day (8 hours) will be provided to employees in
each department which, in the judgment of the City Manager, achieves or
exceeds preset departmental goals and objectives for the 12 month period
preceding December 1 of any calendar year. The third such incentive personal
day (8 hours) will be provided to employees who, in the judgment of the City
Manager, achieve or exceed preset health and/or wellness goals for the
12-month period preceding December 1 of any calendar year.  The incentive
personal days earned shall be credited to the personal leave balance of the
affected employees on December 1 of each calendar year and must be used
before June 1 of the following year.



   (D)   Unless otherwise specified in this section, personal days off
must be taken during the year in which they accrue.  With the exception of
incentive personal days off, employees may not carry unused personal days
forward to the next calendar year.

§ 35.17  HEALTH CARE INSURANCE OPTION.



   (A)   Employees of the Public Works and Water Works Department who
are eligible for health care insurance coverage under the village plan, and
who have health care insurance through the employer of a spouse, may elect
not to participate in the health insurance program offered by the village. 
Upon satisfactory proof of adequate coverage through the spouse's employer,
the City Manager may authorize the payment of a $4,000 incentive to employees
opting out of full family coverage.  The election of this option may be made
during the first week of the first month of the health insurance plan year. 
Payment of the incentive shall be made with the first pay period following
the election of this option.



   (B)   In the event that an employee's spouse loses health care
coverage, and the employee or spouse/family is accepted back into the village
health care insurance program, the employee shall be responsible for
reimbursing the village on a pro rata basis for the previously paid incentive.



   (C)   This health care insurance option shall not be available to
otherwise eligible employees when the spouse is also an employee of the
village and the spouse's alternative health care insurance coverage is also
provided by the village.



(Ord. 22-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 26-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
13-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 23-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 18-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 31-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 15-05, passed
12-12-05; Am. Ord. 24-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 19-07, passed 12-17-07;

08-16, passed 12-12-16; Am. Ord. 13-17, passed 12-18-17)



§ 35.18  TERMINATION BENEFITS.



   Employees who retire from the Public Works and Water Works Departments
in good standing are eligible to receive termination benefits as set forth in
§ 35.65 and in the Personnel Policies and Regulations for Non-Uniformed
Employees.  Retiring employees are only eligible to receive such termination
benefits one time.



(Ord. 08-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 15-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.
09-13, passed 12-16-13; Am. Ord. 10-14, passed 12-15-14; Am. Ord. 11-15,
passed 12-14-15; Am. Ord. 08-16, passed 12-12-16; Am. Ord. 13-17, passed
12-18-17)



§ 35.19  EMPLOYEE MERIT PROGRAM.



   (A)   There is hereby established an employee merit based program.
The purpose of this program is to provide an annual budget appropriation to
the City Manager to be used to award those full-time, non- contract employees
who have demonstrated exemplary service highlighted through the successful
completion of a specific project, task or accomplishment which exemplifies
the village mission and departmental goals. Annual appropriations to this
program are not guaranteed.



   (B)   Any merit awarded by the City Manager shall not be based upon
hourly compensation at time and one-half nor shall exempt employees lose
their exempt status by participating in the program. The amount and timing of
merit solely shall be within the discretion of the City Manager through
recommendations from department heads. The employees who are eligible for the
program shall be determined at the discretion of the City Manager.



   (C)   The amount of any merit and the employees who shall receive
such merit may vary from year to year. Any merit awarded shall not increase
the employee’s base salary in the determination of annual compensation nor
shall the failure to award merit or the award of a lesser amount from year to
year considered as disciplinary action or as a decrease in performance.



(Ord. 13-17, passed 12-18-17)



REGULATIONS FOR PERMANENT EMPLOYEES



§ 35.30  COMPENSATION FOR ADMINISTRATIVE AND NON-DEPARTMENTAL EMPLOYEES.



   (A)   The rates of compensation for administrative and
non-departmental employees of the village are hereby adopted according to
ordinance, and shall be payable bi-weekly.  Unless otherwise specified in
this subchapter, all seasonal employees of the village shall not be eligible
to receive any other benefits provided in this subchapter. Permanent,
part-time employees, who are eligible to receive benefits, shall receive
benefits as specified in this subchapter. Unless otherwise specified the
permanent part-time employees eligible to receive such benefits include:
custodian and inspector.



   (B)   With respect to the Administrative Assistant and the Rowe
Arboretum Manager, all hours worked in excess of 40 hours per week will be
compensated in accordance with F.L.S.A. regulations.



   (C)   The positions of Village Clerk/ Comptroller, Assistant City
Manager, Finance Director/Tax Commissioner, City Engineer/Project Manager,
Director of Administrative Services, Rowe Arboretum Manager, Administrative
Assistant, Administrative Assistant-Ranger, and Information Technology
Manager and other part-time positions shall be exempt from the Merit System
Ordinance of 1970.



   (D)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to fix the compensation
in cases where ranges are indicated in accordance with a supplemental step
increase plan maintained by the City Manager.



   (E)   Unless otherwise specified in this subchapter, the personnel
regulations for non- uniformed employees of the Water Works Department and
Public Works Department, as amended to the effective date of this subchapter,
shall govern further details of salary administration and working conditions
of hourly paid employees.

§ 35.31  ANNUAL LONGEVITY PAYMENT.



   (A)   Permanent, full-time employees of the village, with at least
five years of continuous service to the village, shall receive an annual
longevity payment in addition to their regular compensation in accordance
with the following schedule:



YEARS OF SERVICE   PAYMENT



5 through 9 years      $900



10 through 14 years      1,000



15 through 19 years      1,100



20 through 24 years      1,200



25 or more years      1,350



   (B)   Permanent, part-time employees who were hired prior to January
1, 2003 shall receive an annual longevity payment in an amount proportional
to the above schedule and the actual number of hours worked by that employee.



   (C)   The longevity payment will be made annually during the first
week in December to those qualified employees of record, who have or will
have completed the specified number of years service on or before December 31
of that year.



   (D)   In case of death, retirement or resignation, longevity pay
will be pro rated based on the number of completed months actually worked
during the calendar year and paid as part of the terminal benefit lump sum.

§ 35.33  SICK LEAVE.



   Each employee shall be entitled for each completed month of service to
sick leave of one and one-quarter days with pay.  Unused sick leave shall be
cumulative up to 120 days, unless more than 120 days are approved by the City
Manager.



   (A)   Incentive pay for unused sick leave.



      (1)   Permanent, full-time employees of the village who have
accumulated a sick leave balance of 90 days (720 hours) shall be compensated
annually for 33.3% of the number of hours in excess earned, not to exceed 15
days (120 hours) each year times the hourly rate of base pay in effect at the
time such payment is made. The actual payment to an employee in any one year
shall not exceed 40 hours of pay.  The remaining unused sick leave, not to
exceed ten days (80 hours) per year shall be accumulated with the original
90-day balance to a maximum allowable sick leave balance of 120 days (960
hours).  The number of benefit hours shall be based upon a 12-month
reporting period of December 1 through November 30.  Payment shall be made
during the first week of December in each year.



      (2)   Permanent, part- time employees, who were hired or with
service with the village prior to January 1, 2003, shall accrue sick time and
receive incentive pay in proportion to hours worked.



   (B)   Payment for accrued sick time upon retirement.  Any employee
retiring from village service will be paid one-half of his accrued sick leave
up to a maximum payment of 60 days pay.



   (C)   Transfer of sick leave accumulated from employment with
another Ohio public agency.  Any employee who has prior service with another
Ohio public agency may transfer any unused and/or uncashed sick leave
balance, up to a maximum of 960 hours, to the village. It shall be the
responsibility of the employee to provide satisfactory documentation
substantiating the uncashed sick leave being transferred from his or her
prior employer. Any such sick leave accumulated while employed by another
Ohio public agency shall, upon exhaustion of sick leave accumulated while
employed by the village, be available for use by the employee under the
applicable sick leave use provisions contained in the personnel policies.
Transferred sick leave shall not be eligible for compensation under either
the annual incentive pay program specified under Incentive Pay For Unused
Sick Leave or the retirement compensation specified under Payment for Accrued
Sick Leave Upon Retirement. The maximum combined usable balance of village
accumulated and transferred sick leave that can carry over for future use
shall not exceed 960 hours on December I of any year.



(Ord. 22-90, passed 12-17-90; Am. Ord. 24-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord.
28-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord. 15-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 25-99,
passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 20-03, passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 33-04, passed
12-20-04; Am. Ord. 17-05, passed 12-12-05; Am. Ord. 26-06, passed 12-18-06;
Am. Ord. 20-07,  passed 12-17-07; Am. Ord. 09-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord.
16-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord. 10-13, passed 12-16-13; Am. Ord. 11-14,

12-12-16; Am. Ord. 02-17, passed 4-24-27; Am. Ord. 15-17, passed 12-18-17)



§ 35.34  VACATION LEAVE.



   (A)   Vacation leave applicable to employees hired prior to January
1, 2003.



      (1)   Full-time employees covered by this subchapter who were
hired prior to January 1, 2003 shall be entitled to two calendar weeks (ten
work days) of vacation with full pay after service of one year, including
prior service with other governmental units in Ohio.



      (2)   Employees having five or more years of service,
including prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled,
during each year thereafter, to three calendar weeks (15 work days) of
vacation leave with full pay.



      (3)   Employees having 20 or more years of service, including
prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled, during
each year thereafter, to four calendar weeks (20 work days) of vacation leave
with full pay.



      (4)   Employees who do not use all of their annual vacation
before the end of the current year may carry over up to one-half of their
annual vacation leave entitlement to the following year. In no event shall
the amount of vacation leave that is carried-over to a subsequent year exceed
one-half of the employee's annual entitlement.



      (5)   Permanent, part- time employees, who were hired, or had
service with the village prior to January 1, 2003, shall be entitled to
vacation leave in proportion to hours worked and based on years of service,
including service with other governmental units in Ohio.



   (B)   Vacation leave applicable to employees hired after January 1,
2003. 



      (1)   Full-time employees covered by this subchapter who begin
employment after January 1, 2003 shall be entitled to accrue 3.077 hours of
vacation per pay period, or two calendar weeks (ten work days) of vacation
leave annually, including prior service with other governmental units in Ohio.



      (2)   Employees having five or more years of service,
including prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled,
during each year thereafter, to accrue 4.615 hours of vacation per pay
period, or three calendar weeks (15 work days) of vacation leave annually,
with full pay.



      (3)   Employees having 20 or more years of service, including
prior service with other governmental units in Ohio, are entitled, during
each year thereafter, to accrue 6.154 hours of vacation per pay period, or
four calendar weeks (20 workdays) of vacation leave annually, with full pay.



      (4)   Part-time Grand Valley Preserve Workers who were hired
before January 1, 2003 are entitled to accrue vacation hours proportional to
the hours worked during the preceding calendar year.  Vacation accrual rates
shall be based upon two calendar weeks proportional to hours worked on an
annual basis.



      (5)   The City Manager shall have the discretion to set
vacation accruals for those positions which are exempt from civil service
regulations and involve the hiring of individual employees who have
substantial private sector experience. In no event shall the vacation accrual
authorized exceed the maximum accruals authorized by this section for
employees who have prior service with other governmental units in Ohio.



      (6)   In no event shall the amount of vacation leave that is
carried on the village vacation accrual records for any employee covered
under this section exceed 150% of the employee's annual entitlement.



(Ord. 24-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 28-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
15-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 25-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 20-03,
passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 33-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 17-05, passed
12-12-05; Am. Ord. 26-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 20-07,  passed 12-17-07;
Am. Ord. 09-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 16-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.
10-13, passed 12-16-13; Am. Ord. 11-14, passed 12-15-14; Am. Ord. 12-15,

4-24-27; Am. Ord. 15-17, passed 12-18-17)



§ 35.35  FUNERAL LEAVE.



   Permanent employees of the village shall be permitted to take two days
off, without credit to vacation or sick leave, for the purpose of attending
the funeral of a family member.  At the discretion of the City Manager, this
leave may be extended to a maximum of three days for the funeral of a
relative where the employee may be required to be responsible for
arrangements or travel long distances.



(Ord. 24-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 28-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.

passed 12-15-03; Am. Ord. 33-04, passed 12-20-04; Am. Ord. 17-05, passed
12-12-05; Am. Ord. 26-06, passed 12-18-06; Am. Ord. 20-07,  passed 12-17-07;
Am. Ord. 09-10, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 16-11, passed 12-19-11; Am. Ord.

passed 12-14-15; Am. Ord. 10-16, passed 12-12-16; Am. Ord. 02-17, passed
4-24-27; Am. Ord. 15-17, passed 12-18-17)



§ 35.36  PERSONAL TIME OFF.



   (A)   Permanent employees of the village who are covered by this
subchapter shall be permitted to take one work day (8 hours)off per year with
pay as personal time off, subject to the advance approval of the City
Manager.  Employees must work at least six months during their first
calendar year of employment in order to be eligible to take a personal day
during that year.



   (B)   Permanent employees shall accrue one additional personal day
off per year upon the first day of any calendar year following their
respective fifth, tenth, fifteenth, twentieth and twenty-fifth anniversaries
marking uninterrupted service with the village, subject to the advance
approval of the City Manager.



   (C)   Permanent employees shall be eligible for up to three
additional incentive based personal days off each year. One such additional
day (8 hours) will be provided for any employee who does not use any sick
time for the 12 month period preceding December 1 of any calendar year. The
second such incentive personal day (8 hours) will be provided to employees in
each department which, in the judgment of the City Manager, achieves or
exceeds preset departmental goals and objectives for the 12 month period
preceding December 1 of any calendar year. The third such incentive personal
day (8 hours) will be provided to employees who, in the judgment of the City
Manager, achieve or exceed preset health and/or wellness goals for the
12-month period preceding December 1 of any calendar year. The incentive
personal days earned shall be credited to the personal leave balance of the
affected employees on December 1 of each calendar year and must be used
before June 1 of the following year.



   (D)   Permanent, part-time employees, who were hired prior to
January 1, 2003, shall be entitled to personal time off based upon
uninterrupted service time with the village.



   (E)   Unless otherwise specified in this section, personal days off
must be taken during the year in which they accrue. With the exception of
incentive personal days off, employees may not carry unused personal days
forward to the next calendar year.



(Ord. 24-91, passed 12-16-91; Am. Ord. 28-95, passed 12-18-95; Am. Ord.
15-98, passed 12-21-98; Am. Ord. 25-99, passed 12-20-99; Am. Ord. 20-03,

§ 35.37  HEALTH CARE INSURANCE OPTION.



   (A)   Employees of the village who are eligible for health insurance
coverage under the village plan, and who have health care insurance through
the employer of a spouse, may elect not to participate in the health
insurance program offered by the village.  Upon satisfactory proof of
adequate coverage through the spouse's employer, the City Manager may
authorize the payment of a $4,000 incentive to employees opting out of full
family coverage.  The election of this option may be made during the first
week of the first month of the health insurance plan year.  Payment of the
incentive shall be made with the first pay period following the election of
this option.



   (B)   In the event that an employee's spouse loses health care
coverage, and the employee or spouse/family is accepted back into the village
health care insurance program, the employee shall be responsible for
reimbursing the village on a pro rata basis for the previously paid incentive.



   (C)   This health care insurance option shall not be available to
otherwise eligible employees when the spouse is also an employee of the
village and the spouse's alternative health care insurance coverage is also
provided by the village.  The health care insurance option shall not be
available to permanent part-time employees who receive health care insurance
as part of a retirement package from a previous employer.

   Employees who retire from the village in good standing are eligible to

   (A)   There is hereby established an employee merit based program.
The purpose of this program is to provide an annual budget appropriation to
the City Manager to be used to award those full-time, non- contract employees
who have demonstrated exemplary service highlighted through the successful

   (B)   Any merit awarded by the City Manager shall not be based upon

   (C)   The amount of any merit and the employees who shall receive

PERSONNEL REGULATIONS



§ 35.40  PERSONNEL RULES OF THE MANAGER AND PERSONNEL ADVISORY AND APPEALS
BOARD.



   The personnel rules of the manager and the rules of the personnel
advisory and appeals board, are approved and promulgated as the rules of the
manager and the personnel advisory and appeals board.  Copies of these rules
and all amendments are on file at the village offices. 



('80 Code, § 34.02) (Ord. 23-71, passed - -71)



§ 35.41  MANDATORY RETIREMENT AGE.



   Each and every employee of the village shall retire at the age of 65
years.  However Council may extend from year to year the retirement of any
employee upon a determination by the City Manager that it is to the best
interests of the village, that any employee continue in the service of the
village for said year. 



('80 Code, § 34.03) (Ord. 19-66, passed 5-24-66)



§ 35.42  REIMBURSEMENT FOR MEAL EXPENSES AND NON-SALARY REMUNERATION.



   (A)   The village may provide refreshments, including beverages and
meals, provisions for parties, awards in recognition of service to the
municipality, trophies, and other types of non- salaried remuneration that
inure to the benefit of officers or employees of the municipality or to
others when the City Manager determines that such expenditures promote morale
in the municipal service or the civic interest of citizens or others whose
civic participation inures directly or indirectly to the benefit of the
village.



   (B)   The village may reimburse the Mayor and the City Manager and
the administrative directors and their subordinates for such expenses as they
may reasonably incur for meals purchased for themselves and others when the
City Manager determines that such expenditures directly or indirectly promote
the public interest or municipal objectives.  The City Manager shall
establish rules governing the submission of expenses and the reimbursement
therefor.



('80 Code, § 34.04) (Ord. 12-82, passed 11-29-82)



§ 35.43  VILLAGE TO "PICK-UP" EMPLOYEE CONTRIBUTIONS TO CERTAIN STATE FUNDS.



   (A)   Effective September 29, 1984, the full amount of the
statutorily required "employee contributions" to the state retirement systems
of police and firemen's disability and pension fund or the public employee's
retirement system shall be withheld from the gross pay of each employee of
the village who is a member of those retirement systems and shall be
"picked-up", (assumed and paid to those retirement systems), by the
village.  This "pick-up" is and shall be designated as "employee
contributions" and shall be in lieu of individual contributions to the
retirement systems of police and firemen's disability and pension fund or the
public employee's retirement system by each such employee.  No employee
subject to this "pick-up" provision shall have the option of choosing to
receive the statutorily required "employee contribution" to those retirement
systems instead of having it "picked-up" by the village.



   (B)   The village through its proper officers shall, in reporting
and making remittance to the police and firemen's disability and pension fund
and public employee's retirement system of the state, attest that "pick-up"
of the employee's contribution for each employee subject to this procedure
has been made by the village in lieu of direct contributions to those
retirement systems by each such employee and the contributions are designated
as "employee contributions".



('80 Code, § 34.05) (Ord. 10-84, passed 9-24-84; Am. Ord. 20-08, passed
12-15-08)



§ 35.44  RESERVED.



§ 35.45  PURCHASE OF ADDITIONAL SERVICE CREDIT.



   (A)   Upon August 26, 2002 employees of the village described in
division (B) of this section, may purchase additional service credit,
tax-deferred, and the village shall withhold the required service credit
deduction from the gross pay of each person who elects to do so and shall
pick up (assume and pay) such deduction to the Ohio Police and Fire Pension
Fund or the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio. A person electing
this pick up deduction shall not have the option of choosing to receive the
payroll deduction directly instead of having this deduction picked up by the
village.  Members who have elected to participate in this plan cannot
increase, decrease, or terminate the amount of the pick up deduction.



   (B)   The pick up deduction by the village as provided by this
section shall apply to all persons making the election within the following
classes:  All full-time or permanent part-time employees of the village who
are contributing members of the Ohio Police and Fire Pension Fund or Public
Employees Retirement System of Ohio.



   (C)   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to
implement the provisions of this section to effect the pick up of the payroll
deduction for the purchase of additional service credit to the Ohio Police
and Fire Pension Fund or Public Retirement System for those persons within
the classes established in division (A) of this section.



(Ord. 17-02, passed 8-26-02)



MERIT SYSTEM



§ 35.50  COMPETITIVE EXAMINATIONS.



   Appointments and promotions in the service of the village shall be made
according to merit, to be ascertained, as far as practicable, by competitive
examination. 



('80 Code, § 34.10) (Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70)



§ 35.51  EXEMPT POSITIONS.



   All positions in the service of the village shall be filled pursuant to
§ 35.50 except the following:



   (A)   Mayor.



   (B)   Members of the Council.



   (C)   Members of boards and commissions.



   (D)   City Manager.



   (E)   Assistant to the City Manager.



   (F)   Heads of the principal departments.



   (G)   Police Chief.



   (H)   Assistant Chief - Captain of Patrol and Assistant Chief -
Captain of Investigations.



   (I)   City Solicitor.



   (J)   Controller - Clerk of Council.



   (K)   Secretary to the City Manager.



   (L)   Project Manager.



   (M)   IT Manager.



   (N)   Grand Valley Manager



   (O)   Temporary employees of exceptional professional or scientific
qualifications engaged as consultants for limited periods of time.



   (P)   Such unskilled labor as the personnel advisory and appeals
board finds impracticable to include in the classified service.



('80 Code, § 34.11) (Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70; Am.  Ord.  16-83, 
passed  11-21-83; Am. Ord. 17-87, passed 9-28-87; Am. Ord. 01-16, passed
2-22-16)



§ 35.52  DIRECTOR OF PERSONNEL.



   The Manager, with the approval of the personnel advisory and appeals
board, shall appoint a director of personnel, to serve part-or full-time. 
The appointee may have another position with the village administration, or
the manager may, with the board's consent, appoint himself.  The director of
personnel shall:



   (A)   Conduct recruitment of qualified persons for village positions;



   (B)   Prepare, schedule, and hold examinations; but nothing in this
section shall prevent him from cooperating with other merit system agencies
with regard to any phase of examination;



   (C)   Create eligible lists from results of examinations;



   (D)   Certify eligibles to appointing authorities for appointment or
promotion;



   (E)   Establish a job classification plan and allocate the various
village positions to classes within the plan;



   (F)   Certify payrolls to assure that all appointments have been
made within the provisions of this chapter;



   (G)   Develop and conduct training programs;



   (H)   Perform such other duties relating to personnel as the manager
may direct;



   (I)   Act as secretary to the personnel advisory and appeals board. 



('80 Code, § 34.12) (Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70)



§ 35.53  PERSONNEL ADVISORY AND APPEALS BOARD.



   (A)   There shall be a personnel advisory and appeals board of three
members, appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Council, for terms of
six years.  Provided, the first board shall consist of one member appointed
for a term ending December 31, 1972, one for a term ending December 31, 1974,
and one for a term ending December 31, 1976.  Thereafter all terms shall be
for 6 years.  Any vacancy within a term shall be filled for the unexpired
portion.



   (B)   Each member of the board shall be a resident of the village,
neither shall hold nor be a candidate for any other public office or
employment, and shall not be a member of any local, state or national
committee of a political party or an officer of any partisan political club
or organization. 



('80 Code, § 34.13)(Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70)



§ 35.54  DUTIES OF THE BOARD.



   The board shall serve without compensation and shall:



   (A)   Hear appeals from any nonexempt employee who has been
suspended longer than five days, dismissed from the village service, or
demoted to a lower grade and salary;



   (B)   Hear appeals concerning rejection of applications for
employment and the conduct of examinations;



   (C)   Approve or modify the rules proposed by the manager;



   (D)   Establish its own rules and procedures governing the conduct
of the board's business; and



   (E)   Make such investigations of village personnel practices as it
deems necessary to carry out its responsibilities. 



('80 Code, § 34.14) (Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70)



§ 35.55  APPEAL FROM DISCIPLINARY ACTION.



   Whenever an employee, whose position is not exempt from merit system
requirements, and who has passed his probationary period as set forth in the
rules of the manager, is disciplined by dismissal, suspension of longer than
five days, or demotion to a lower grade and salary, he may appeal to the
board, under rules set forth by the board.  If his appeal meets the
conditions of the rules, the board shall hear his appeal within 30 days of
the effective date of the disciplinary action.  After hearing the evidence
on which disciplinary action was based, and the employee explanation, the
board shall render a judgment, either to affirm, reverse, or modify the
decision of the appointing authority; and such judgment shall be final.  In
hearing any appeal, the board shall have the power to subpoena witnesses and
require the production of records.  The board may also promulgate such
additional rules as may be required to carry out the provisions of this
section.  ('80 Code, § 34.15) (Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70)



§ 35.56  RULES OF THE CITY MANAGER.



   The Manager shall prepare rules and regulations necessary to carry out
a system of merit employment, and forward these rules to the personnel
advisory and appeals board.  The board, after public hearing, shall make
such modifications as it sees fit, and forward the rules, as modified, to the
Council.  The Council shall have the power to accept these rules or to
return them to the board for further consideration; but the Council shall
have no authority to amend the rules.  Upon approval by Council, the rules
shall have the force and effect of law.  Amendments may be made from time to
time, following the procedure for original adoption. 



('80 Code, § 34.16) (Ord. 12-70, passed 4-27-70)



   SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT PLAN



§ 35.65  TERMINAL LEAVE PAY.



   Each employee of the village who has been in service of the village for
ten years, upon retiring or leaving the service, with and upon recommendation
of the head of such employee's department of work, shall be entitled to and
shall be paid one month's pay. In addition the employee shall be entitled to
and shall be paid, upon retiring or leaving the service, 1/10 of one month's
pay for each additional year of service to the village.  For this purpose a
month's pay shall constitute the employee's final base rate of pay for one
month, or for 190 hours in the case of hourly personnel.



(Ord. 22-03, passed 12-15-03)
