GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 36.01  OFFICIALS AUTHORIZED TO SIGN CHECKS.



   Any two of the following officials of the village are authorized to
sign checks on the deposit funds of the village:



   (A)   City manager;



   (B)   Comptroller; or



   (C)   Chairman of the finance committee of Council. 



('80 Code, § 36.01) (Ord. 10-67, passed 1-24-67)



§ 36.02  CREATION OF PROPERTY RENTAL RECEIPTS ACCOUNT.



   (A)   There is created a Code 14 within the General Fund of the
village to be known as the property rental receipts account to take effect as
of January 1, 1969.



   (B)   The City Manager is authorized to make such expenditures out
of the code for making repairs to the properties of the village from which
rentals are received, providing the expenditures are not in contravention
with the provisions of the Charter of the village with respect to
expenditures by the City Manager and provisions of the Charter with respect
to expenditures except upon publicly advertised bids. 



('80 Code, § 36.02) (Ord. 28-69, passed 9-29-69)



§ 36.03  ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND FOR RECEIPTS OF INCOME TAX PAYMENTS; USES.



   (A)   There is created a fund into which receipts from the village
income tax are to be paid and in which such proceeds are to be retained until
properly disbursed.



   (B)   The comptroller is authorized and directed to establish a fund
to be called the income tax fund wherein receipts from the income tax are to
be retained and accounted for.  The moneys so retained in the income tax
fund may be used to cover the appropriate salary, office, and other expenses
of the tax commissioner.  The balance of the moneys in the fund may be
transferred to the credit of the general fund of the village from time to
time. 



('80 Code, § 36.03) (Ord. 29-73, passed 12-17-73)



§ 36.04  ESTABLISHMENT OF FEDERAL GENERAL REVENUE SHARING TRUST FUND.



   (A)   There is established a special fund to be known as the federal
general revenue sharing trust fund under the provisions of R.C. § 5705.14.



   (B)   All moneys paid to the village under the State and Local
Fiscal Assistance Act of 1972 shall be credited to the fund and expended in
accordance with the terms and provisions of the federal act.



('80 Code, § 36.04) (Ord. 28-72, passed 11-27-72)



§ 36.05  ESTABLISHMENT OF PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION FUND.



   There is established a public transportation fund of the village to
which shall be credited all money received as fares for transportation of
persons on public conveyances operated by or for the village, together with
any incidental receipts from the operation.



('80 Code, § 36.05) (Ord. 34-42, passed 6-23-42)



§ 36.06  CREATION OF CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT RESERVE FUND.



   (A)   There is created a capital improvement reserve fund of the
village, in accordance with the provisions of § 19 of the Charter of the
village.  No expenditure from the capital improvement reserve fund shall be
made except pursuant to appropriation by the City Council and no such
appropriation shall be made except to purchase equipment, apparatus or other
property, or to construct buildings, structures, roads and other improvements
needed for the use of the village, or to pay obligations of the village by
means of transfer to the bond interest and retirement fund of the village.



   (B)   Council may from time to time transfer into the capital
improvement reserve fund any balance in any other fund of the village, not
needed for the purpose of such fund, and there shall be transferred to the
reserve fund the unencumbered balance remaining in the general fund of the
village at the end of any fiscal year.



('80 Code, § 36.06) (Ord. 44-42, passed 12-29-42)



§ 36.07  CREATION OF GIFT FUND FOR PECUNIARY GIFTS.



   (A)   There is created a gift fund in which pecuniary gifts made to
the village are retained and accounted for.



   (B)   The comptroller is hereby authorized and directed to establish
a fund to be called gift fund wherein pecuniary gifts made are retained and
accounted for.  The expenditures therefrom shall be made by the comptroller
in accordance with the donative intent of the donor of any such gift and upon
order of the manager within authority duly made by Council. 



('80 Code, § 36.07) (Ord. 25-71, passed 9-27-71)



§ 36.08  CREATION OF CAMP JIM B PURCHASE FUND.



   There is established a special fund for the purpose of holding the
amount of $100,000, previously appropriated in Ordinance No. 11-80, for the
purchase of Camp Jim B.  The Manager is authorized to make such investments
as are appropriate, consistent with any applicable law, and as will yield the
highest yield available within the legal requirements, in consultation with
the Holding Committee of the Indian Hill Rangers Boy Scout Camp
Incorporated.  The Manager will pay over to the Holding Committee of the
Indian Hill Rangers Boy Scout Camp Incorporated the income derived each year
from the monies contained in the fund hereby created.



('80 Code, § 36.08) (Ord. 29-81, passed 12-21-81)



§ 36.09  CREATION OF DRUG OFFENDER FUND.



   (A)   A drug offender fines fund is hereby established to enable the
village to receive mandatory fines imposed upon felony drug offenders and
forfeited bail from such offenders pursuant to R.C. § 2925.03 and to expend
funds in the furtherance of law enforcement efforts that pertain to drug
offenders.



   (B)   The City Manager, or his designee, is authorized to make
expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose which is consistent with
the purpose for which this fund is established.



(Ord. 2-89, passed 1-30-89)



§ 36.10  CREATION OF CRIMINAL ACTIVITY FORFEITURE FUND.



   (A)   The criminal activity forfeiture fund is hereby established to
enable the village to receive the assets accumulated by persons convicted in
the course of their criminal enterprises and to expend funds in the
furtherance of law enforcement purposes.



   (B)   The City Manager, or his designee, is authorized to make
expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose which is consistent with
the purpose for which this fund is established.



(Ord. 3-89, passed 1-30-89)



§ 36.11  DEPOSITS OF INACTIVE AND INTERIM FUNDS.



   The Manager and the Comptroller hereby are authorized to award inactive
and interim deposits not only to the highest bidder, but, when and in such
proportions as the Manager and Comptroller shall determine, to award a
portion of said deposits to such other financial institutions as may bid
within one tenth of one percent of the highest bidder, in order to spread the
risk to the safety of such deposits.



(Ord. 26-91, passed 12-16-91)



§ 36.12  INTEREST ON SPECIAL FUNDS.



   All interest on special funds of the village, unless otherwise directed
by village ordinance, shall be paid into the special fund which has generated
that interest.



(Ord. 27-91, passed 12-16-91)



§ 36.13  DUI ENFORCEMENT AND EDUCATION FUND.



   (A)   A DUI enforcement and education fund is hereby established to
enable the village to receive mandatory fines imposed by the state upon
offenders of state statutes related to driving while under the influence of
alcohol (DUI) pursuant to R.C. § 4511.99 and to expend funds in the
furtherance of law enforcement and public education efforts the pertain to
DUI offenses.



   (B)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, is authorized to
make expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose that is consistent
with the purpose for which this fund is established.



(Ord. 11-01, passed 6-18-01)



§ 36.14  LAND ACQUISITION FUND.



   (A)   A fund is hereby established to be known as the land
acquisition fund, into which shall be deposited the proceeds from the sale of
the Land Acquisition Bond Anticipation Notes and any donations or gifts
received by the village for the purchase of the property.



   (B)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, is hereby authorized
to make expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose that is consistent
with the purpose for which the land acquisition fund is established,
including, without limitation the redemption prior to maturity of Land
Acquisition Bond Anticipation Notes to the extent that amounts on deposit in
the land acquisition fund exceed the amount necessary to acquire the property
pursuant to division (C) of this section.



   (C)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to expend up to
$6,560,000 from the land acquisition fund for the purchase of the 304 acre
parcel on Glendale Milford Road in Camp Dennison, Symmes Township, Hamilton
County, Ohio, and incidental costs related to the purchase and/or the fees
and costs associated with the issuance of the Land Acquisition Bond
Anticipation Notes.



(Ord. 09-02, passed 4-22-02)



§ 36.15  EMPLOYEE HEALTH REIMBURSEMENT INSURANCE FUND.



   (A)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to establish an employee
reimbursement insurance fund.



   (B)   All funds paid pursuant to division (A) shall be deposited in
the fund, and that such funds be expended, as and when directed by the City
Manager or City Council, for the purpose of reimbursing employees for
eligible expense established under the FSA and HRA plans.



   (C)   The City Council hereby authorizes the City Manager to
establish a Flexible Spending Account and Health Reimbursement Arrangement
Plan for all eligible city employees under Section 125 and 106 of the
Internal Revenue Code.



   (D)   City Council hereby authorizes the City Manager to execute all
necessary agreements, contracts, resolutions, instruments, and other
documents required to establish the plan, including third party
administrative charges.



(Ord. 21-03, passed 12-15-03)



§ 36.16  MAYOR'S COURT COMPUTER FUND.



   (A)   The Mayor is hereby authorized and directed, in addition to
any other court costs, to charge and collect from each defendant thereafter
convicted in Mayor's Court special costs in the sum of $10, subject, however,
to the right of the Mayor to waive payment of such costs.



   (B)   All court costs collected pursuant to division (A) shall be
deposited in the Mayor's Court computer fund, established herein, and that
such funds be expended, as and when directed by the City Manager or City
Council, for the purchase of computer hardware, software and technological
expenses for the Mayor's Court.



(Ord. 23-03, passed 12-15-03)



§ 36.17  LAW ENFORCEMENT ASSISTANCE FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby established a fund to be known as the Law
Enforcement Assistance Fund. The necessity for establishing this fund is to
provide for separate accounting records for revenues and expenditures
associated with the state-mandated police officer annual training in
accordance within R.C. §§ 109.802 and 109.803.



   (B)   The City Manager, or his or her designee, is authorized to
make expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose that is consistent
with the purpose for which this fund is established.



(Ord. 02-08, passed 1-28-08)



§ 36.18  RETIREMENT BENEFIT RESERVE FUND; RETIREMENT BENEFIT RESERVE WATER
WORKS FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby established a fund to be known as the
Retirement Benefit Reserve Fund and Retirement Benefit Reserve Water Works
Fund. The necessity for establishing these funds is to provide for separate
accounting records for revenues and expenditures associated with retirement
vacation, sick leave and longevity leave pay.



   (B)   The City Manager, or her designee, is authorized to make
expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose that is consistent with the
purpose for which this fund is established.



(Ord. 06-14, passed 12-15-14)



§ 36.19  FIREHOUSE CONSTRUCTION FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby established a fund to be known as the
Firehouse Construction Fund. The necessity for establishing this fund is to
provide for separate accounting records for revenues and expenditures
associated with the construction of the Indian Hill Firehouse.



   (B)   The City Manager, or her designee, is authorized to make
expenditures from the fund for any lawful purpose that is consistent with the
purpose for which this fund is established.



(Ord. 07-14, passed 12-15-14)



GREEN AREAS AND RECREATIONAL FUND



§ 36.20  CREATION OF GREEN AREAS AND RECREATIONAL FUND.



   The village declares itself trustee of a fund to be known as the green
areas and recreational fund of the village and hereinafter referred to for
convenience as the "fund". 



('80 Code, § 36.10) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.21  THE TRUST RES.



   There is appropriated from the general fund of the village a sum for
the establishment of the fund; and upon the payment into a separate bank
account under the name set forth in § 36.20, such fund shall be deemed to be
established and the village the trustee thereof.



('80 Code, § 36.11) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.22  USES AND PURPOSES.



   The purpose of the fund shall be exclusively public for the benefit of
the residents of the village to provide for the care, maintenance, and
administration of the green spaces, forest preserves, bridle trails, bird
sanctuaries, shooting ranges, recreational and public areas within or without
the village and such other grounds as are devoted by the owners to any of the
aforesaid or to similar public purposes. 



('80 Code, § 36.12) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.23  CONTRIBUTIONS AND PURCHASES.



   (A)   All contributions made to or purchases made by the village and
specified to be used for such uses and purposes shall be deposited in the
fund and used, expended or conveyed only in accordance with the declaration
of trust.



   (B)   Contributions may be made in cash, securities, or other
property, tangible or intangible, or in real estate, and the fund is
empowered to receive and the trustee is empowered to purchase such property
as may be beneficial to the uses and purposes of the trust.



   (C)   Any contributions may be specified to be an endowment gift and
thereby permanently appropriated to the uses and purposes of the fund, in
which event the village, as trustee, shall use only the income derived from
the contributions. 



('80 Code, § 36.13) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62; Am. Ord. 21-81, passed
11-23-81)



§ 36.24  SEPARATION OF ASSETS OF FUND.



   The fund and all its assets shall be kept separate and apart from all
other funds and assets administered by the village and not commingled with
any other funds or assets whatsoever. 



('80 Code, § 36.14) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.25  ACCOUNTING AND BOOKKEEPING.



   Proper books of account shall be kept in accordance with customary
municipal accounting and so that the status of the fund shall be clearly and
accurately shown at all times.  Upon request of any resident of the village,
a full report and accounting shall be rendered as promptly as the same can be
prepared.



('80 Code, § 36.15) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.26  EXPENDITURES AND DISBURSEMENTS.



   Expenditures and disbursements shall be made only upon the signature of
the City Manager and the city comptroller for the uses and purposes stated in
§ 36.22 and in pursuance of the powers set forth in § 36.28, provided, that
the City Manager shall be the administrator of the fund under the general
control and direction of Council consistent with municipal practice as
established by the Charter and the statutes of the state.



('80 Code, § 36.16) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.27  UNIFORM DEPOSITORY ACT.



   The fund shall be subject to the Uniform Depository Act as contained in
R.C. §§ 135.01 through 135.23 and upon the establishment of the fund, the
City Manager shall comply therewith.



('80 Code, § 36.17) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.28  POWERS.



   (A)   Trustee shall hold and administer the fund, and shall have
full power to invest the assets of the fund in real estate or in bonds and
securities and to sell such securities and to transfer, convey, and dispose
of the same upon the terms, and in the manner, and for the prices as the
trustee shall deem wise and proper, except that the trustee may sell only
such real property as is not otherwise encumbered by deed or other lawful
restriction, and is not part of the funds of the trust; as to real property
which is, or has been given same only in exchange for, or as part of a
unified transaction or series of transactions which shall result immediately
in the trust receiving real property of like or better quality than that
which is so conveyed, in the discretion and opinion of the trustee.



   (B)   Conforming to the limitations in this section, the trustee is
invested with full power and authority to invest and reinvest all or any part
of the fund upon such terms and for such length of time as the trustee shall
deem meet and proper.  It being intended, subject to the limitations in this
section, to give the trustee full and complete authority to hold, possess,
manage, control, sell, convey, encumber, lease, invest, and reinvest the
whole and every part of the fund according to its judgment and discretion in
accordance always with the provisions of the trust.



   (C)   The trustee is invested with power and authority to protect,
exchange, partition, subdivide, grant, and convey title or any lesser
interest with or without covenants of warranty, lease, for a term of years
for any duration whatsoever or perpetually with or without privilege of
purchase, and to do and perform any and all other proper acts in respect of
any and all real estate or any interest therein and any improvements thereon,
and to insure against fire or any other risks, maintain, repair, alter,
improve, construct, reconstruct, or demolish said improvements in accordance
always with the provisions of the trust.



   (D)   Third parties dealing with the trustee need not inquire as to
the application of moneys received by it, nor as to his authority to take
action with respect to the assets of the fund.



   (E)   The trustee is directed to charge all premiums on investment
against principal.  Any and all cash dividends, whether ordinary or
extraordinary, shall  be  considered as  income  and any and all stock
dividends or other things of value normally considered  as corpus and 
shall be added to the capital of the fund.  The trustee, in his discretion,
may apportion to principal or income any  expenditure  which in  his
opinion should be so apportioned, notwithstanding any legal rule to the
contrary.



   (F)   The trustee may deduct, retain, and reimburse himself for all
costs, taxes, damages and assessments as may be due against the fund, or
which it may have paid or been put to by reason thereof.



('80 Code, § 36.18) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62; Am.  Ord.  8-76,  passed
- - ;  Am.  Ord.  21-81,  passed 11-23-81)



§ 36.29  GREEN AREAS ADVISORY COMMITTEE.



   (A)   The Mayor shall appoint a committee composed of no less than
five and no more than 17 residents of the village and shall serve for terms
of 3 years, to advise and consult with the City Manager with respect to the
administration of the fund and the application of available funds for
specific uses within the uses and purposes of the fund as set forth in §
36.22.



   (B)   The chairman of the public buildings and grounds committee and
the chairman of the planning and boundaries committee shall be made members
of the committee herein provided for, with all the same duties and privileges
belonging to the other members.



   (C)   After the expiration of the respective terms of the residents
appointed by the Mayor on June 26, 1962, each member of the advisory
committee shall serve for a term of five years.



('80 Code, § 36.19) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62; Am.  Ord.  8-76,  passed
- - ; Am. Ord. 3-78, passed 2-6-78)



§ 36.30  DISSOLUTION.



   (A)   The trust may be amended by the Council in order to improve
its administration, but no such amendment shall alter, change, or amend §
36.22 or this section so as to divert any of the assets of the fund from the
uses and purposes of § 36.22.



   (B)   In the event the trustee is unable to carry out the uses and
purposes for any reason and it becomes necessary to terminate or dissolve the
trust, upon a determination thereof by the county court of common pleas, the
moneys and assets of the fund shall be placed in the capital improvements
reserve fund of the village and the trust shall cease. 



('80 Code, § 36.20) (Ord. 21-62, passed 5-22-62)



§ 36.31  CREATION OF GREEN AREAS ACQUISITION FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby created within the Green Areas and
Recreational Fund of the village the Green Areas Acquisition Fund, and it is
hereby directed that a separate account be set up on the financial records of
said Green Areas Fund.



   (B)   Any contributions or appropriations placed in the Acquisition
Fund shall be held in the Fund and utilized for the purchase of real property
to be used as green areas.



   (C)   The village may invest and reinvest the assets of the
Acquisition Fund and the income thereof applied to the principal under the
investment criteria set forth in § 36.28 hereof, or otherwise as provided by
the laws of the state for municipal trustees.



   (D)   The village may, from time to time, place in or accept
contributions to said Acquisition Fund, and when the contributions are placed
therein, expenditures from the Acquisition Fund shall be in accordance
herewith.



(Ord. 28-89, passed 10-23-89)



§ 36.32  CREATION OF GREEN AREAS AND RECREATIONAL UNRESTRICTED FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby created within the Green Areas and
Recreational Fund of the village the Green Areas and Recreational
Unrestricted Fund, and it is hereby directed that a separate account be set
up on the financial records of the Green Areas Fund.



   (B)   Any contribution placed in the Unrestricted Fund and any
interest generated therefrom shall be held in the Fund and utilized for any
purpose deemed appropriate by the Council for the care, preservation and
improvement of the Green Areas of the village as well as acquisitions
thereto, whether or not that specific purpose is set forth herein, or as a
purpose of the Green Areas and Recreational Fund, the Green Areas and
Recreational Endowment Fund, the Green Areas Acquisition Fund, or any other
fund hereafter created for the enhancement of the green areas.



   (C)   The village may invest and reinvest the assets of the
Unrestricted Fund and the income therefrom applied to the principal under the
investment criteria set forth in § 36.28 hereof, or otherwise as provided by
the law of the state for municipal trustees.



   (D)   The village may, from time to time, place in or accept
contributions to said Unrestricted Fund, and when the contributions are
placed therein, expenditures from the Unrestricted Fund shall be in
accordance herewith.



(Ord. 28-89, passed 10-23-89)



§ 36.33  CREATION OF GREEN AREAS AND RECREATIONAL ENDOWMENT FUND.



   (A)   There is hereby created within the Green Areas and
Recreational Fund of the village a Green Areas and Recreational Endowment
Fund.  It is hereby directed that a separate account be set up on the
financial records of the Green Areas and Recreational Fund of the village.



   (B)   Any moneys or other property placed in the Green Areas and
Recreational Endowment Fund shall be held in the fund and the income only
thereof used for the upkeep, maintenance, and administration of green and
recreational areas of the village.  Moneys from the Endowment Fund cannot be
transferred to the Unrestricted Fund or the Acquisition Fund, established
by  §§ 36.31 and 36.32.



   (C)   The village may, from time to time, place in or accept
contributions to said Green Areas and Recreational Endowment Fund, and when
the moneys or property are placed therein, said Funds shall be administered
in accordance herewith.



   (D)   Securities now held by the village in the Green Areas and
Recreational Fund shall be accounted for as part of the Green Areas and
Recreational Endowment Fund.



(Ord. 29-89, passed 10-23-89)



§ 36.34  CREATION OF MAINTENANCE FUND.



   There is hereby created a Maintenance Fund within the Green Areas
Fund.  This Maintenance Fund shall hold, receive, and account for the income
of the Endowment Fund.  Unused income may accrue to the principal in the
Endowment Fund.  Unused income at the end of any calendar year may be
accumulated, carried over, and spent from year to year; or the unused income
may accrue to the principal in the Endowment Fund.  The City Council shall
make the decisions regarding the disposition of such unused income.



(Ord. 29-89, passed 10-23-89)



FUND FOR STANLEY M. ROWE ARBORETUM



§ 36.40  CREATION OF GREEN AREAS TRUST FUND FOR STANLEY M. ROWE ARBORETUM.



   There is created a fund known as the " Trust Fund for the Stanley M.
Rowe Arboretum".  This fund is to be used  for the care, maintenance and
improvement of the Stanley M. Rowe Arboretum.



('80 Code, § 36.30) (Ord. 30-81, passed 12-21-8l; Am. Ord. 21-87, passed
11-23-87)



§ 36.41  ESTABLISHMENT OF ARBORETUM ADVISORY COMMITTEE.



   In order to carry out the care and maintenance of the Stanley M. Rowe
Arboretum, there is created an Advisory Committee to advise the Council and
the Manager as to that care, maintenance and improvement required by the
Arboretum.  The Committee shall consist of five persons to be appointed by
the Mayor.



('80 Code, § 36.31) (Ord. 30-81, passed 12-21-8l; Am.  Ord.  16-87, 
passed  6-15-87; Am. Ord. 21-87, passed 11-23-87)



§ 36.42  EXPENDITURES FROM ARBORETUM FUND.



   The Manager is empowered to make expenditures from the Arboretum Fund
as the care, maintenance and improvement of the Stanley M. Rowe Arboretum is
required; provided however:



   (A)   The excess income from the fund not used for maintenance,
upkeep and repair of the Arboretum shall be accumulated in the fund to the
extent deemed necessary by the Council for the village and the balance may be
used for the maintenance, upkeep and repair of the other green areas within
the village.



   (B)   If there are excess funds, either income and in the judgment
of the Council excess principal, the excess income and/or the excess
principal may be used to purchase additional property for Arboretum purposes
and it is requested that such use be made of such funds, but if not so used,
shall nevertheless be used for green area purposes.



('80 Code, § 36.32) (Ord. 30-81, passed 12-21-8l; Am. Ord. 21-87, passed
11-23-87)

THE VILLAGE BULLETIN



§ 37.01  ESTABLISHMENT; TITLE.



   There is established an official newspaper of the village which shall
be known as The Village Bulletin, and which shall be regularly published not
less frequently than once each month. 



('80 Code, § 37.01) (Ord. 17-42, passed 4-28-42)



§ 37.02  DUTY OF THE CITY MANAGER.



   It shall be the duty of the City Manager under the direction of Council
to edit, manage, publish, and distribute The Village Bulletin.  The size,
form, typography, make-up, number of copies to be printed, publication date,
method of distribution, and similar details relating to the publication of
the newspaper shall be determined by the City Manager. 



('80 Code, § 37.02) (Ord. 17-42, passed 4-28-42)



§ 37.03  CONTENTS.



   The Village Bulletin may contain ordinances and resolutions which are
passed by Council; resolutions adopted by various boards and commissions of
the village; notices, announcements, and advertisements required by law or
ordinance to be published; official reports of the proceedings of Council;
information concerning the official actions of all departments, boards, and
commissions of the village; proposals for bids for public contracts and such
other matters as Council may authorize.  In addition, The Village Bulletin
may contain news or happenings of local or foreign interest, or both, such as
social, political, business, professional, editorial, or other kindred
subjects intended for the information of the general reading public. 



('80 Code, § 37.03) (Ord. 17-42, passed 4-28-42)



§ 37.04  EXPENSE PAID FROM THE GENERAL FUND.



   The expense of publishing, editing, and distributing The Village
Bulletin shall be paid from the appropriations from the general fund for the
office of the City Manager and the office of the city clerk for publication
of ordinances and proceedings. 



('80 Code, § 37.04) (Ord. 17-42, passed 4-28-42)



OFFICIAL BONDS



§ 37.10  BLANKET BOND FOR EMPLOYEES.



   A blanket bond shall be given in the amount of $200,000 for each
employee of Indian Hill and the chairman of the finance committee. (Members
of the police department shall be covered for honest performance of duty
only.)



('80 Code, § 37.05) (Ord. 7-83, passed 5-16-83)



§ 37.11  OTHER OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES; BONDS REQUIRED.



   (A)   In addition to the foregoing blanket bond, the following
officials shall give bond in the amount of $75,000 each:



      (1)   City manager



      (2)   Assistant city manager



      (3)   Clerk/comptroller



   (B)   The tax commissioner shall give a separate bond in the amount
of $75,000.



('80 Code, § 37.06) (Ord. 7-83, passed 5-16-83)



§ 37.12  APPROVAL; INDEMNITY COMPANY; PREMIUMS.



   Official bonds required of officers or employees of the village shall
be subject to approval as to form by the city solicitor.  The sureties
thereon shall be an indemnity company or companies authorized to do business
in the State of Ohio.  Premiums on official bonds described above given to
the village shall be paid out of moneys appropriated by the Council.



('80 Code, § 37.07) (Ord. 5-42, passed 1-14-42; Am. Ord. 7-83, passed
5-16-83)



§ 37.13  CONDITION OF OFFICIAL BONDS.



   The condition of every official bond shall be that the officer or
employee covered thereby will honestly, faithfully, and impartially discharge
all and every duty belonging or appertaining to his office, and will
faithfully and honestly preserve, protect, and account for all money,
property, and things of value belonging to the village which come into his
possession and custody.  It shall be a sufficient accounting by the
comptroller of moneys charged to him to show that such moneys have been
deposited in a solvent bank to the credit of the village, in accordance with
the laws of the state or ordinance of the village, governing the deposit of
such moneys.



('80 Code, § 37.08) (Ord. 5-42, passed 1-14-42; Am. Ord. 7-83, passed
5-16-83)



§ 37.14  DEPOSITING BONDS.



   The official bonds shall be deposited with and safely kept by the clerk.



('80 Code, § 37.09) (Ord. 5-42, passed 1-14-42; Am. Ord. 7-83, passed
5-16-83)



   REGULATIONS OF PROPERTY OWNED BY VILLAGE



§ 37.20  POLICE AND SANITARY REGULATIONS OF PROPERTY OWNED BY THE VILLAGE.



   All police and sanitary regulations of the village shall apply with
equal force and effect within and upon all real property owned and to be
owned from and after May 29, 1973, by the village, and the rangers shall have
full police power and authority with respect to such real property.



('80 Code, § 37.10) (Ord. 9-73, passed 5-29-73)



   INDEMNIFICATION OF COUNCIL MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES



§ 37.30  INDEMNIFICATION OF COUNCIL MEMBERS, OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.



   (A)   The village shall, except as provided in division (B) of this
section, indemnify any current or former elected or appointed officer,
employee or member of a board or commission of the village, whether or not
such person is compensated for such service, from liability incurred in the
performance  of his duties  by paying  any judgment in, or amount
negotiated in settlement of, any civil action arising under federal law, the
law of Ohio or the ordinances of the village.  The reasonableness of the
amount of any consent judgment or settlement shall be subject to the review
and approval of the Solicitor and the City Council. The foregoing
indemnification provisions shall include indemnification for the cost of
defense of any such action.  The foregoing shall apply to the
indemnification of any Council member, officer or employee while acting on
behalf of the village as Trustee of the Green Areas and Recreational Fund
trust.



   (B)   The village shall not indemnify a Council member, officer or
employee under any of the following circumstances:



      (1)   To the extent the Council member, officer or employee is
covered by a policy of insurance for civil liability purchased by the village;



      (2)   When the Council member, officer or employee acts
manifestly outside the scope of his employment or official responsibilities,
or with malicious purpose, or in bad faith, or in a wanton or reckless manner;



      (3)   For any portion of a judgment that represents punitive
or exemplary damages;



      (4)   For any portion of a consent judgment or settlement that
is unreasonable.



   (C)   The village may purchase a policy or policies of insurance on
behalf of officers and employees of the village providing coverage for
amounts in excess of $1,000,000 per occurrence incurred in connection with
any civil action, demand, or claim against the Council member, officer or
employee by reason of any act or omission by the Council member, officer or
employee occurring in the performance of his duties and not coming within the
terms of division (B)(2) of this section.



   (D)   This section does not affect any of the following:



      (1)   Any defense that would otherwise be available in an
action alleging personal liability of a Council member, officer or employee;



      (2)   The operation of R.C. § 9.83.



   (E)   The indemnification of Council members, officers or employees
against judgments or settlements pursuant to this section shall be
accomplished only through the following procedure:



      (1)   If the village determines that the actions or omissions
of its Council member, officer or employee who is to be indemnified were not
within the terms of division (B)(2) of this section, an indemnity agreement
shall be prepared by the Solicitor, specifying that the village will
indemnify the Council member, officer or employee from a particular judgment
that has been rendered or a particular settlement amount that has been
negotiated.  The agreement shall name the person or entity to whom payment
by the village of the judgment or settlement amount will be made, and the
agreement shall not be effective until it is approved by the Council member,
officer or employee to be indemnified, the Solicitor and the City Council. 
The Solicitor shall approve the indemnity agreement unless he finds that
division (B) of this section prohibits the village from indemnifying the
Council member, officer or employee, or prohibits the village from
indemnifying the Council member, officer or employee for a portion of a
judgment or settlement and the indemnity agreement would indemnify the
Council member, officer or employee for all or part of that portion.



      (2)   If sufficient moneys have not been appropriated, the
City Council shall appropriate sufficient funds to pay the indemnification,
and no payment shall be made until the appropriation has been made.



   (F)   A Council member, officer or employee may commence an action
against the village in a court of competent jurisdiction to prove that he is
entitled to indemnification pursuant to division (A) of this section and that
division (B) of this section does not prohibit or limit his indemnification
and seeking either a judgment against the village for a sum of money that the
Council member, officer or employee has paid to satisfy a judgment or
settlement or an order directing the village to pay a judgment or settlement
against the Council member, officer or employee which has not been satisfied.



   (G)   An action brought pursuant to this section shall be commenced
no later than two years after the cause of action arising under this section
accrues.  A cause of action arising under this section accrues upon the
entry of a money judgment against the Council member, officer or employee if
the time for filing an appeal in the action lapses without the filing of an
appeal; upon the conclusion of the final appeal in any action in which a
money judgment is entered against the Council member, officer or employee if
an appeal is filed in the action; or upon execution of any settlement
agreement requiring payment of money by the Council member, officer or
employee.



(Ord. 13-88, passed 10-24-88)



DISSEMINATING NOTICES



§ 37.40  DISSEMINATING STATUTORY NOTICES CONCERNING SEXUAL PREDATORS AND
HABITUAL SEX OFFENDERS.



   (A)   The Chief of Police, upon receipt of the notice from the
County Sheriff or the Ohio Attorney General pursuant to R.C. § 2950.11, or
the administrative regulations adopted under authority of R.C. § 2950.13
(hereinafter 2950 Notice) in addition to any notice required under R.C.
Chapter 2950 and any regulations adopted thereunder, shall provide a copy of
the 2950 Notice to all residences located within a radius of one-quarter mile
of the address listed within the 2950 Notice of the residence of the sexual
predator or habitual sex offender.  The Chief of Police shall send such
notice within 72 hours of the receipt of the 2950 Notice from the County
Sheriff or Ohio Attorney General.  The delivery of this notice may be
accomplished by personal delivery to a principal adult occupant of the
residences in the area described above, or by mailing a copy of the notice by
ordinary U.S. Mail addressed to the owner of principal occupant of the
residences in the affected areas as such owner or principal occupant is
identified within the business records maintained by the Police Department.



   (B)   The procedure set forth in this section is not intended to
create a cause of action against any official, administrative officer,
employee or agent of Indian Hill, nor is the procedure adopted herein
intended in any way to impact the immunity extended to such persons pursuant
to R.C. § 2950.12.  Such statutory immunity is reserved to all protected
individuals and organizations as outlined in R.C. § 2950.12 or successor
statute.  As a public record subject to publication and disclosure, this
section is intended to provide a procedure for effectively disseminating the
public information provided to the Police Department concerning sexual
predators or habitual sex offenders residing within the community.  The
procedure adopted herein is intended to ensure appropriate public safety, and
it is not intended to create any obligation upon the Police Department nor
any official or employee of the village to disseminate such information or to
create liability for the failure to disseminate such information in a timely
and complete manner.

CHAPTER 50:  SEWER REGULATIONS



Section



General Provisions



   50.01   Village to collect sewer service charges



Household Sewage Disposal Regulations

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 50.01  VILLAGE TO COLLECT SEWER SERVICE CHARGES.



   The village will bill and collect from its residents a charge for
sewerage service for and on behalf of the county, and the county will pay to
the village for the billing and collecting of the sewer service charge an
amount equal to 7% of the amount collected.



('80 Code, § 51.01) (Ord. 2-77, passed 10-14-77)



HOUSEHOLD SEWAGE DISPOSAL REGULATIONS



§ 50.10  SEWAGE DISPOSAL.



   The rules and regulations of the Ohio Department of Health as codified
at Ohio Administrative Code Chapter 3701-29 as they presently exist and as
amended, are adopted, where applicable, as the rules and regulations of the
village pertaining to the design, installation, maintenance, repair and
operation of any sewage treatment system (as defined at O.A.C. 3701-29-01) in
the village. Discharges and treatment of sewage from any property or
structure within the village other than to a sewage treatment system, shall
comply with the applicable rules and regulations of the Metropolitan Sewer
District of Greater Cincinnati and/or the Ohio Environmental Protection
Agency.



(Ord. 04-17, passed 5-22-17)

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 51.01  CREATION OF DEPARTMENT OF WATER WORKS.



   There is created a department of water works of the village which shall
administer and operate the works and the water distribution system in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and operating code of the
department of water works set forth herein, and as they may be duly amended
from time to time.



('80 Code, § 52.01) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.02  CREATION OF OFFICE OF SUPERINTENDENT.



   There is created the office of the superintendent of the water works
who shall be in charge of the department of water works of the village and
who shall operate and administer matters in connection therewith in
accordance with the terms of this chapter.



('80 Code, § 52.02) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.03  APPOINTMENT OF CITY MANAGER AS SUPERINTENDENT.



   The City Manager is appointed as the superintendent of the department
of water works.  However council may, by resolution hereafter adopted,
separate the function of the City Manager and the superintendent of the
department of water works. 



('80 Code, § 52.03) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.04  PROHIBITIONS.



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to deposit filth or any deleterious
substance or commit any damage or nuisance of any kind upon the grounds set
apart for the use of the water works or any part or portion of the water
works system.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to waste water by leaving
open a hydrant or faucet connected to the water works system and to allow
water to flow from same when such water is not being used.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person not theretofore authorized
by the superintendent, or other proper officer of the village, to open any
street, lane, or road or other public way for purpose of taking water, or to
tap any pipes, or to abuse any property, or to make attachments to any water
pipes belonging to the village.



   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person not theretofore authorized
by the superintendent to tamper with or to do harm to or to attempt to do so,
any portion of the water works system or to any part of the water works
system upon the premises of private owners unless authorized by the owner.



   (E)   If shall be unlawful for any person, other than an employee of
the village to use a fire plug on the water system, or to use thereon any
wrench or tool other than a regulation fire department spanner, except in
case of emergency, without first having secured from the superintendent a
license for such use.



   (F)   If shall be unlawful for anyone other than an authorized
employee of the department to remove a meter without the permission of the
superintendent.  When a meter has been unlawfully removed, it shall be
unlawful to use water supplied by the service branch to which the meter was
attached.  Where a meter is found to have been unlawfully removed, the water
shall be shut off forthwith and not turned on again until payment has been
made for the estimated amount of the water used in addition to any fine that
may be imposed.



('80 Code, § 52.40) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.05  ENFORCEMENT.



   The city solicitor is authorized, upon the request of the
superintendent to go into any court, in law or in equity, to enforce any
provision hereof. 



('80 Code, § 52.41) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.06  BACKFLOW PREVENTION.



   (A)   The Indian Hill Water Works shall conform to this rules of the
Ohio Environmental Protection Agency, Chapter 3745-97 of the Ohio
Administrative Code, which shall be a part of this chapter herein by
reference.



   (B)   A backflow prevention device shall be installed on all new
water services prior to any point of connection or usage. A backflow
prevention device shall be installed on existing water services as determined
necessary by the Water Works Superintendent. The user shall, at his/her own
expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner
approved by the Water Works Superintendent or his/her agent, and shall have
inspections and tests made of such approved devices as required by the Water
Works Superintendent.



   (C)   The Water Works Superintendent shall cause surveys and
investigations to be made on properties served by the Water Works where
actual or potential hazards to the public water supply exist. Such surveys
and investigations shall be repeated as often as the Water Works
Superintendent shall deem necessary.



   (D)   All backflow prevention devices shall be approved by the Water
Works Superintendent and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.



   (E)   Any property in violation of backflow prevention and
cross-connection control regulations shall be subject to discontinuance of
service by the Water Works Superintendent. Service shall not be restored
until conditions conforms to regulations.



   (F)   For all residential units, five-family or less, a dual check
valve backflow prevention device, ASSE Standard 1024, shall be required,
unless otherwise specified by the Water Works Superintendent.



   (G)   For all non-residential commercial users, and for residential
units greater than five-family, a double check valve backflow prevention
device, ASSE Standard 1015, shall be required, unless otherwise specified by
the Water Works Superintendent.



(Ord. 06-98, passed 6-29-98)



§ 51.07  WATER SERVICE AGREEMENT WITH VILLAGE OF MILFORD.



   (A)   The village will supply water to certain users of the Village
of Milford Water System who are located west of the Little Miami River, and
that water supplied by Indian Hill will be paid for by the Village of
Milford, at the same rate charged all other customers.



   (B)   Insofar as it is possible for the parties to do so, each
relieves the other from any damage occasioned to the other's system, or its
customers' private system, by reason of differences in pressure, or
otherwise, in the event water is used pursuant to the terms of this agreement.



   (C)   This agreement shall be in effect for the term of five years,
provided, however, that either party may cancel the agreement upon written
request to the other, and said cancellation shall not take effect until 90
days after the notice of cancellation except with the consent of the other
party.



('80 Code, § 52.51) (Ord. 2-82, passed 3-1-82)



§ 51.08  PROVISION OF MUNICIPAL SERVICES.



   The Superintendent of the Department of Water Works shall cause water
to be furnished free of charge to the Water Tower located at 5535 Miami, Camp
Dennison Park; Camp Stepping Stones; Rheinstrom Park; the Rowe Arboretum; the
Livingston Lodge; and fountain associated therewith; the Historical Society;
the Village Service Department, the Ranger Lodge, the Village Shooting Range,
and any other structure or fountain located on 7100 Glendale-Milford Road; a
sprinkler located at 6525 Drake Road; the Buckingham Lodge; the Boy Scout
Camp located at 7940 Shawnee Run; the Waldschmidt House located on
Glendale-Milford Road; the Stephan Ball Fields, the fountains and lake
associated therewith, located at Drake and Shawnee Run; the Bird Sanctuary
located at Drake and Shawnee Run; the Clippinger Woods Trough; the Kugler
Mill Road soccer fields, the Camp Livingston restrooms, and the Grand Valley
Preserve.



(Ord. 12-99, passed 6-21-99; Am. Ord. 13-08, passed 9-29-08)



WATER MAIN INSTALLATIONS



§ 51.20  INSTALLATIONS.



   Except as specifically provided by ordinance, all construction of water
main extensions and water tap service in streets and ways not already
supplied with water shall be in accordance with one of the following
sections: §§ 51.21 through 51.25.



('80 Code, § 52.05) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.21  PAYMENT OF ENTIRE COST IN ADVANCE.



   Any one or more property owners may request the superintendent to
determine the feasibility and the estimated cost of the construction of a
proposed water main extension to serve his or their premises.  If the
superintendent shall approve the extension and determine the estimated
construction cost, the property owner or owners may deposit with the
department a sum equal to the estimated cost and the superintendent shall
thereupon proceed with the construction.  Any surplus in the deposit amount
over and above the construction cost shall be refunded to the owners or their
agents. Should the construction cost exceed the deposit amount, the owner or
owners shall pay the excess amount, the agreement for which shall be made at
the time of the original deposit.  No water tap shall be installed or water
service rendered from the extension until the cost is paid in full.



('80 Code, § 52.06) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.22  CONSTRUCTION BY OWNERS.



   In undedicated streets and in new subdivisions, the superintendent may
permit an owner or owners to arrange for the laying of water main extensions
by private contract; the performance of the work, however, shall be done
under the supervision and control of the superintendent.  In the
construction of any such extension the contractor shall use only duly
inspected and approved materials and in any case the superintendent may
require a deposit of a reasonable amount as a guarantee against defective
workmanship or materials and for inspection and supervision charges.  Each
deposit, less any sums expended by the department for inspection, or for
repair or replacement of defective work or materials, shall be refunded one
year after the extension has been placed in service.  No other refund of
payment shall be made.



('80 Code, § 52.07) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.23  FIFTY PERCENT PETITION.



   In the case of existing dedicated streets, the superintendent shall be
authorized to construct water main extensions where practicable upon
application of the owners of 50% or more of the abutting foot frontage to be
served by the proposed extension, accompanied by payment per linear abutting
foot of property owned by the petitioners.  The original amount of payment
per linear foot and refund of any surplus shall be determined as in §
51.21.  When an extension has been constructed in accordance with this
section, water tap connections to such extension shall be permitted only to
serve premises for which the front foot charge has been paid at the time of
the filing of the petition, provided that the owners of other property
abutting the extension may be permitted to make a tap or connection upon
payment of a sum equal to the original amount per linear foot plus 15% per
linear abutting front foot of the premises owned by them.



('80 Code, § 52.08) (Am. Ord. 9-96, passed 4-22-96)



§ 51.24  CONSTRUCTING WITHOUT PETITION.



   (A)   When council of the village determines by ordinance that it is
to the best interest of the water distribution system to construct a water
main extension connecting two or more existing mains, the superintendent of
water works shall be authorized to construct such an extension without the
filing of any petition therefor or the making of any advanced deposit. 
After the completion of any such extension, the superintendent shall cause
any premises abutting the streets or way in which the extension is laid to be
notified of the installation and that a tap may be made thereto upon payment
per linear foot to be determined as in § 51.21.



   (B)   No taps shall be permitted to be made in any extension until
and unless the payment herein shall be paid in full.  The above payment is
in addition to the normal charge for service branch installations indicated
in § 51.37.



('80 Code, § 52.09) (Am. Ord. 9-96, passed 4-22-96)



§ 51.25  ASSESSMENT IN ACCORDANCE WITH STATE LAW.



   The owners of property to be served by a proposed water main extension
may petition for the construction of the extension and the assessment of the
cost thereof in accordance with the provisions of state law.



   (A)   The size, materials, and all other specifications to be used
in the construction of any water main shall be determined by the
superintendent, in accordance with "Engineering and Plumbing Requirements" to
be promulgated by him and kept on file by him in his office.  The
requirements shall be kept up to date by the superintendent and shall be open
to public inspection at all times. Copies of the requirements may be
distributed by the superintendent as may be determined by him from time to
time.



   (B)   No water main extension shall be constructed on any new street
or any undedicated street unless the location of the street has been approved
by the village planning commission and until all the requirements of all
other ordinances, if any, have been complied with.



   (C)   No water main extension shall be laid in any unimproved street
whose profile is such that in case of the improvement of the street, it would
be necessary to relay the main to conform with the then established grade and
no water main shall be constructed under the provisions of § 51.23, where,
owing to the topography of the territory abutting the street, or to other
conditions, further property development is precluded or is unlikely.



   (D)   The superintendent shall maintain a record of all charges
outstanding against premises abutting streets improved with water main
extension in accordance with § 51.23 or § 51.24.  The record shall be
suitably indexed as to streets and part of streets, and shall at all times be
available for public inspection.  With the consent of the county auditor, a
duplicate copy of the record shall be kept on file in the office of the
county auditor for the convenience of title examiners and prospective
purchasers of real estate.  As the charges are paid or as new charges are
imposed, the necessary notation shall be made in that record by way of
amendment or supplement.  The notation by way of amendment or supplement
shall be copied into the county auditor's duplicate record at intervals of
not more than 30 days.  The record shall at all times be accompanied by a
statement from the superintendent indicating the date to which the record has
been carried.



('80 Code, § 52.10) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.26  RETAIL SERVICE AREA AND SPECIAL BENEFIT DISTRICT SERVED BY CITY OF
CINCINNATI WATER WORKS.



   (A)   There is established a retail service area for the City of
Cincinnati Water Works inside the village described in the water agreement by
and between the City of Cincinnati and the City of the Village of Indian
Hill, dated December 21, 1984, as the area bounded on the west, north, and
east by the Indian Hill corporation line and on the south generally bounded
by the south line of Section Number 34 of Symmes Township, and the south line
of Section Number 4 of Sycamore Township.



   (B)   A portion of that service area, comprised of parcels listed in
the Appendix, is herewith defined as being the area benefited by the 12-inch
trunk water distribution main constructed in Hopewell Road and Montgomery
Road as shown on approved plan, Cincinnati Water Works Job No. 4- 1837, dated
January 16, 1985, at village expense in the public interest for supplying
water to that area in adequate quantities and pressures for domestic use and
fire suppression.



   (C)   The benefited properties are identified on the Appendix to
this chapter by a listing compiled from the Hamilton County Auditor's
property records, showing book, page, parcel number, and gross acreage.



   (D)   Provision is made for owners of those properties within that
benefited area to obtain water service from this 12-inch trunk water
distribution main by a direct tap/connection or indirectly by a system of
public water main extensions or loops with this distribution main.



   (E)   Owners or their agents desiring water service within the
benefited area shall make application for such service jointly to the
director of the Cincinnati Water Works and to the superintendent of Village
Water Works.  No service branch or service main shall be approved or
installed until the owner of the benefited property, as set forth in the
Appendix, shall have paid, in advance, to the village a tap-in fee,
calculated on the district rate/acre in effect at the time of application,
times the total number of acres being benefited or having the potential for
being benefited as a result of the service line applied for.



      (1)   Tap-in fees for water main extensions intended to serve
a subdivision shall be calculated on the basis of gross acreage of the entire
subdivision receiving benefit.



      (2)   Tap-in fees for water service branches serving a single
residential dwelling, not part of a subdivision, shall be calculated on the
gross acreage of the parcel on which the dwelling is being constructed and
receiving benefit.



      (3)   The tap-in fees shall be paid in addition to any other
established permit fee or construction charges incurred for the installation
of water main extensions or service branches.



      (4)   In the event that a large parcel, for which the tap-in
fee has been paid, is later subdivided further, no additional tap-in fees
will be applied for service branches required to serve the additional
dwellings on the same tract of land; however, normal fees and costs for the
service branch installation will be charged.



      (5)   The Superintendent of Village Water Works shall maintain
accurate records of the parcels subject to paying tap-in fees and shall
establish and administer the procedure for collecting those fees.  The
initial tap-in fee shall be calculated on the basis of total project cost,
including engineering, inspection, construction, interest charge, if any, and
total acres being benefited.  Fees shall be adjusted no less than at least
once every five calendar years to reflect an interest charge being paid on
bond anticipation notes or other securities being used to finance the water
main to serve this district, commencing at the date of completion of
construction and placing in service of said water main.  He shall arrange
for the Appendix to be updated and amended as necessary to indicate payment
of tap-in fees for individual parcels and to record any boundary line changes
which might occur as a result of replatting.



   (F)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, no
tap/connection shall be made to the new 12-inch trunk water line serving the
benefited area, as created in the Appendix, to serve any portion of a
subdivision located in the benefited area, which subdivision's plat was
approved prior to the effective date of this section, in anticipation of an
adequate water supply being available by the construction of the 12-inch
trunk water line, without



there first having been paid a tap-in fee, calculated in the manner set forth
in this section.



('80 Code, § 52.11) (Ord. 11-86, passed 5-19-86; Am. Ord. 06-95, passed
4-24-95; Am. Ord. 6-96, passed 4-22-96; Am. Ord. 11-09, passed 4-20-09; Am.
Ord. 04-11, passed 3-21-11; Am. Ord. 05-12, passed 5-21-12)



SERVICE BRANCHES



§ 51.35  APPLICATION PROCEDURES.



   Any property owner desiring the installation of a service branch into
his premises shall make application through a licensed master plumber as his
authorized agent.  By making application for a service branch, or by using
or permitting use of a service branch already installed, the owner agrees to
be bound by all the provisions of this operating  code and as it may be
amended from time to time, and by the "Engineering and Plumbing Requirements"
promulgated by the Superintendent and all other lawful rules of the
department of water works.



('80 Code, § 52.15) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.36  AUTHORITY OF SUPERINTENDENT REQUIRED.



   No service branch shall be installed to serve property which does not
abut the street or road in which the service main is located except with
authority of the Superintendent and the village planning commission.  Every
residence or user shall have its separate service branch and meter. 
However, a variance in this respect may be authorized by the Superintendent
and the village planning commission if it is shown that the variance will not
be harmful to the water works system, in the present or in the future.  In
authorizing the variance the conditions as may be necessary and proper may be
attached. 



('80 Code, § 52.16) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.37  SERVICE BRANCH REGULATIONS.



   (A)   When a service branch and water meter is installed, so much of
the branch as is in the highway to the front lot line shall be installed by
the Department but shall be paid for by the property owner at the time of the
application for water service, the payment to be as established by ordinance.
Except in cases where service branches are installed for vacant property in
connection with highway improvements, applications for service branch
installations shall be accompanied by application for meters which shall also
be paid for at the time of the application.



      (1)   Only metered water service branches shall be permitted.



      (2)   Branches installed for fire protection shall be subject
to "Engineering and Plumbing Requirements" provided that a branch for any
principal building hereafter constructed shall be provided with one fire
hydrant for every 500 feet of the branch to be no less than eight inches in
diameter.



      (3)   Application for water service shall be made by the owner
of the premises to be supplied, or by his or her authorized agent. Water will
be turned on by an authorized employee of the Department after the
application has been duly filed at the village office.



      (4)   No application for water service will be allowed or no
water shall be supplied to any applicant or consumer where the applicant or
consumer is indebted to the Department for water supplied, work done,
materials furnished or penalties imposed. This section will apply whether the
indebtedness was incurred at the premises for which application is made or at
any other premises supplied by the Department within or without the village
limits.



   (B)   No permit for the erection of a building shall be approved by
the City Manager unless an application for a service branch has been made, or
an application for meter has been made in cases where the service branch has
previously been installed.



   (C)   No water service branch shall at any time be laid in the same
trench with a sewer connection, electrical supply cable or telephone cable.



   (D)   Where any parcel of property is supplied through two or more
connecting service branches each branch shall be equipped with a check valve
so set that water can flow into and not out of the premises and each service
branch shall be equipped with a separate meter.



   (E)   Water service branches shall be the property of the owners of
the property served by them and that portion of the service branch from the
curb cock into the premises served shall be maintained in proper condition by
the owners. Failure to repair a leak or leaks when notified of same within
the time allowed on the notice shall be sufficient cause to justify the
Department in discontinuing water service.



   (F)   No connection into more than one building shall be made from
one tap unless the Superintendent has given his or her approval in writing.



   (G)   No attachment shall be made to any service branch or to any
pipe or other fixture which has been shut off pursuant to this operating code
or order of the Superintendent without first having obtained a permit upon
application duly made, nor shall water be taken from any service branch which
is or has been out of use without such a permit.



   (H)   The original purchase of a meter shall be made by the consumer
but after it has been installed and placed in service, the Department will
assume the maintenance of the meter or its replacement without charge to the
consumer, except that in cases of damage by freezing, hot water, or other
neglect on the part of the consumer, the cost of repairs or replacement shall
be charged to the consumer.



   (I)   Meters shall be fully and substantially set in a workmanlike
manner and in accordance with the "Engineering and Plumbing Requirements".
Meters hereafter installed shall be placed in a frost-proof meter box or pit,
plans for which may be obtained from the Department, and shall be placed at
the front lot line.



   (J)   The Superintendent and authorized employees of the Department
shall have the right at reasonable times to enter any premises where a meter
is installed for the purpose of reading, examining, inspecting, or testing
the same. The Superintendent shall be authorized to fix reasonable charges
for the removal, examination, inspection, testing, and reinstating meters
upon application of the consumer.



   (K)   Meter and service branch charges as set forth in the Appendix
following this chapter, are hereby adopted and shall be effective January 1,
2018. System customers who increase the size of their meter and service
branches shall be responsible for paying a fee equal to the difference in
cost between their present service size and the increase service size as set
forth in the Appendix.



   (L)   There are hereby established Capital Improvement Debt Service
Fees for the purpose of paying a portion of the cost of capital improvements
to the Water Works System and the costs associated with the financing of said
improvements. Said fees shall be in addition to meter and service branch fees
specified under division (K) of this section and shall be deposited in the
Water Works Capital Improvement Reserve Fund. These fees shall be applicable
to all new water system taps made within the Water Works System service area
and shall be in the amounts specified below:



 




Meter Size (inches)

 

Capital Improvement Debt Service Fee

('80 Code, § 52.17) (Am. Ord. 21-95, passed 10-23-95; Am. Ord. 9-96, passed
4-22-96; Am. Ord. 10-97, passed 5-27-97; Am. Ord. 11-03, passed 6-16-03: Am.
Ord. 11-06, passed 4-24-06; Am. Ord. 05-08, passed 4-21-08; Am. Ord. 07-13,
passed 11-18-13; Am. Ord. 06-15, passed 10-19-15; Am. Ord. 19-17, passed
12-18-17)



WATER FOR TEMPORARY USES



§ 51.45  APPLICATION, PERMIT REQUIRED.



   (A)   Where water is required for a temporary use in connection with
the construction of a building or of a highway, or other construction, or for
other temporary operations, on premises not supplied or not sufficiently
supplied with metered water, application shall be made to the Department for
a special permit.  The permit may be granted upon such conditions as the
Superintendent may determine.



   (B)   At the Superintendent's discretion, the Superintendent shall
be authorized to require the use of a special meter to register water
consumed; the meter in such case shall be furnished by the Department upon
payment of $100, to be returned to the permittee following the meter's usage
provided the meter and appurtenances are not damaged during their usage. 
Water shall be paid for on the basis of metered rates according to the actual
or estimated amount used, in addition to an administrative fee of $30.



('80 Code, § 52.20) (Am. Ord. 9-96, passed 4-22-96)

      (2)   Minimum bills.

PAYMENT OF BILLS



§ 51.65  TIME OF PAYMENT.



   Water bills shall ordinarily be payable at intervals of 3 months, but
the Superintendent shall be authorized to provide, in special cases or in
certain classes of accounts, for payment at shorter intervals.  Water bills
shall be paid on or before the date stated on the bill.  The Superintendent
may grant an extension of time for payment, not to exceed 365 days with
interest based upon current interest rates, from the due date, without
penalty, in cases of indigency, relief, and similar conditions, after
investigation.  Partial payments may be accepted, but bills must be paid in
full before the expiration of the approved extension period.



('80 Code, § 52.30) (Am. Ord. 9-96, passed 4-22-96)



§ 51.66  PENALTY FOR NONPAYMENT.



   (A)   Where a water bill has not been paid by the date stated on the
regular bill a collection charge in the amount of 10% of the unpaid balance
will be assessed.  If the bill has not been paid by the date stated on the
delinquent notice, or the date to which the payment has been extended, a
shut-off bill shall be prepared.  A charge of $25 shall be applied to all
accounts scheduled for shut-off.  As soon thereafter as practical, the
shut-off bill shall be presented at the premises and if the same is not paid,
the water shall be shut off immediately, and it shall not, thereafter be
turned on again until all charges due and payable, including advance charges,
if any, are fully paid.  This section shall apply whether or not there has
been in the meantime a change of ownership or possession of the premises
supplied.  A charge of $20 shall be applied to all accounts where checks
received for payment are drawn on accounts with insufficient funds available.



   (B)   The village shall disconnect utility service in accord with
the following policies:



      (1)   When it becomes necessary for the village to discontinue
utility service to a customer for nonpayment of bills, service will be
reinstated only after all bills for service then due have been paid and any
deposit required has been made.  It is the policy of the village to
discontinue utility service to customers by reason of nonpayment of bills
only after notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard on disputed bills.
The village's form for application for utility service and all bills shall
contain, in addition to the title, address, room number, and telephone number
of the official in charge of billing, clearly visible and easily readable
provisions to the effect:



         (a)   That all bills are due and payable on or before
the date set forth on the bill; and



         (b)   That if any bill is not paid by or before that
date, a second bill will be mailed containing a cutoff notice that if the
bill is not paid within ten days of the mailing of the second bill, service
will be discontinued for nonpayment; and



         (c)   That any customer disputing the correctness of his
bill shall have a right to a hearing at which time he may be represented in
person and by counsel or any other person of his choosing and may present
orally or in writing his complaint and contentions to the village official in
charge of utility billing.  This official shall be authorized to order that
the customer's service not be discontinued and shall have the authority to
make a final determination of the customer's complaint.



      (2)   With the exception of approved extensions as specified
in § 51.65, requests for delays or waiver of payment will not be
entertained; only questions of proper and correct billing will be
considered.  In the absence of payment of the bill rendered or resort to the
hearing procedure provided herein, service will be discontinued at the time
specified.



('80 Code, § 52.31) (Am. Ord. 9-96, passed 4-22-96; Am. Ord. 17-97, passed
9-22-97; Am. Ord. 18-17, passed 12-18-17)



§ 51.67  ASSESSING CHARGES.



   The Superintendent shall assess and collect proper charges for water,
materials supplied, and work done.  Any owner of real estate premises
installing or maintaining water service connections shall be considered as
accepting the provisions of all lawful rules and regulations of the
department, and as agreeing, in particular, to be liable for all water and
service charges for the premises, whether the accounts for the premises are
carried in the name of the owner or in the name of tenants or other persons. 



('80 Code, § 52.32) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.68  LEAKAGES.



   No reduction in water charges shall be made for leakage except in cases
where it shall appear, on investigation, that the leakage is underground and
not subject to detection by ordinary methods, and where, further, the owner
and other occupants of the premises are free from negligence in causing or
failing to report the leakage; excepting, also, in cases during periods of
emergency, when, by reason of shortage in materials or manpower, immediate
repairs are not available, where the owner has made diligent efforts to
provide the repairs and has actually employed a plumber to make them, in
which cases an allowance of time of not to exceed 30 days may be granted to
permit the plumber to complete the repairs.  No reduction for leakage shall
be permitted in an amount in excess of 50% of the water bill as rendered.
('80 Code, § 52.33) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.69  CHARGES FOR REPAIRS AND MATERIALS.



   Charges for service rendered or material furnished by the department
shall be chargeable against the owners of the premises served, as in the case
of charges for water.



('80 Code, § 52.34) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.70  BILLS.



   Bills for water supplied, work done or material furnished will be
delivered at the premises or where directed, as a matter of convenience to
the owners of property or their agents.  Failure to receive bills will not
relieve from responsibility for prompt payment.  Duplicate bills may be
obtained upon application. 



('80 Code, § 52.35) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.71  BILLS FOR METER REPAIR AND METER TESTING.



   Bills for meter repair and meter testing shall be paid on or before the
date indicated on the bills. 



('80 Code, § 52.36) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.72  CHARGES PAYABLE FORTHWITH.



   Charges for work done or material furnished, contract bills on main
extensions, improvement charges, main pipe extension charges and final water
bills, shall be payable forthwith.



('80 Code, § 52.37) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)



§ 51.73  DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS.



   Accounts unpaid on the date indicated on the bill shall be considered
as delinquent, and a notice of delinquency shall thereupon be mailed.  If
the account is unpaid on the date shown on the delinquent notice, it shall be
placed in the hands of a turnkey for collection.  When the turnkey cannot
make collection, the water shall be shut off. If a delinquent account remains
unpaid the city reserves the right under the law, to certify same to the
Hamilton County Auditor by a certificate signed by the Finance Director. The
County Auditor shall then place the amount certified by signed certificate on
the appropriate tax duplicate with interest and penalties allowed by law,
including the applicable assessment fee. The same shall be collected as all
other taxes and shall be considered as a lien upon the real property.



('80 Code, § 52.38) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49; Am. Ord. 18-17, passed
12-18-17)



§ 51.74  RESTORATION OF SERVICE.



   If a bill is paid after the water has been shut off, service will not
be restored until the following day.  In addition to charges shown on the
water bill, every delinquent account shall be subject to an additional charge
of $25 for service, whether the turnkey calls for collection or not.



('80 Code, § 52.39) (Ord. 9-96, passed 4-22-96)



§ 51.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in
addition to other penalties provided by law, be fined not less than $25 nor
more than $5,000 or be imprisoned not exceeding 30 days, or both.



('80 Code, § 52.99) (Ord. 5-49, passed 3-29-49)

   GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 52.001  FINDINGS AND PURPOSE.



   (A)   The village is vitally concerned with the use of all
rights-of-way in the village as such rights- of-way are a valuable and
limited resource which must be utilized to promote the public health, safety,
and welfare including the economic development of the village.



   (B)   Changes in the public utilities and communication industries
have increased the demand and need for access to rights-of-way and placement
of facilities and structures therein.



   (C)   It is necessary to comprehensively plan and manage access to,
and structures and facilities in, the rights-of-way to promote efficiency,
discourage uneconomic duplication of facilities, lessen the public
inconvenience of uncoordinated work in the rights-of-way, and promote the
public health, safety, and welfare.



   (D)   The village has authority under the Laws and Constitution of
the State of Ohio, including but not limited to Article 18, Sections 3, 4,
and 7, to regulate public and private entities which use the rights-of-way.



(Ord. 03-02, passed 2-25-02)



§ 52.002  SCOPE.



   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all users of the
rights-of-way as provided herein. To the extent that anything in this chapter
conflicts with Chapter 94, then the provisions of this chapter shall control.



(Ord. 03-02, passed 2-25-02)



§ 52.003  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words,
and their derivations have the meanings set forth herein. When not
inconsistent with the context, words in the present tense include the future
tense, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in
the singular number include the plural number. The words "shall" and "will"
are mandatory and "may" is permissive. Words not defined shall be given their
