   VEHICLE WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS



§ 77.01  WEIGHT RESTRICTIONS ON CERTAIN ROADS.



   (A)   It is declared unlawful for any person to travel any vehicle
with more than two axles on, or for any owner of such vehicle to permit such
vehicle to be driven on, all of the roads or streets of the Village, except
as provided in § 77.01(B)(1) and (B)(2).



   (B)   The axle restrictions set forth in division (A) of this
section shall not apply to the following exceptions:



      (1)   Vehicles in excess of two axles shall be permitted to
travel on Drake Road north of Indian Hill Road, Indian Hill Road between
Miami Road and Drake Road, Loveland-Madeira Road, Miami Road north of Indian
Hill Road, Shawnee Run Road from Drake Road to the western corporation line,
and Remington Road.



      (2)   Vehicles in excess of two axles shall be permitted to
travel on other restricted roads where it is necessary for these vehicles to
travel on these roads for the purpose of loading or unloading within the
corporate limits of the Village.  Provided however, that access by vehicles
in excess of two axles to any restricted roads shall be by the most direct
route from outside the corporate limits or from the permitted travel roads
specified in division (B)(1) of this section. Routing assistance may be
obtained from the Indian Hill Rangers.



   (C)   The manager may erect appropriate signs to advise the public
of the foregoing restrictions.



   (D)   In addition to the penalties provided in § 77.99, the
Solicitor is authorized to seek relief from the acts proscribed herein by the
use of injunctive process and by any other relief in law of in equity which
is available.



('80 Code, § 77.01) (Ord.2-76, passed1-26-76; Am. Ord.22-79, passed10-29-79;
Am. Ord. 22-07, passed 12-17-07; Am. Ord. 03-08, passed 1-28-08)  Penalty,
see § 77.99



   SPEED REGULATIONS



§ 77.05  SPEED IN OVERTAKING A BICYCLE, A PEDESTRIAN, OR A PERSON RIDING OR
LEADING A HORSE.



   The operator of a vehicle overtaking a bicycle, a pedestrian, or a
person riding or leading a horse proceeding in the same direction shall:



   (A)   Slow to a speed which is reasonable for the condition;



   (B)   Exercise due care;



   (C)   Signal to the bicycle or pedestrian, but never signal to the
horse;



   (D)   Pass to the left thereof at a safe distance;



   (E)   Not again increase speed or drive to the right side of the
roadway until safely clear of the overtaken bicycle, pedestrian, or person
riding or leading a horse. 



('80 Code, § 77.05) (Ord. 20-77, passed 6-27-77; Am. Ord. 22-79, passed
10-29-79)



§ 77.06  SCHEDULE OF 25 MILE PER HOUR STREETS.



   (A)   The speed limits for the roads set forth below are 25 miles
per hour.



      (1)   Drake Road south from Varner Road.



      (2)   Keller Road between Loveland-Madeira Road and Given Road.



      (3)   Muchmore Road from Miami Road to the Indian Hill
corporation line.



      (4)   Varner Road from Drake Road to Walton Creek Road.



      (5)   Sycamore Creek Road from Spooky Hollow Road to Given
Road.



      (6)   Spooky Hollow Road from Blome Road to Given Road.



      (7)   Old Indian Hill Road from Indian Hill Road to Indian
Hill Road.



      (8)   Kugler Mill Road from Blome Road to Camargo Road.



      (9)   Weil Road from Hopewell Road north to the Indian Hill
corporation line.



      (10)   Hopewell Road for its entire length.



      (11)   Blome Road between Kugler Mill and Camargo Roads.



      (12)   Given Road, north from Shawnee Run Road, a distance of
one half (.5) mile.



   (B)   The manager is authorized to erect the appropriate traffic
signs upon the roads set forth in division (A) advising motorists of the
speed limitations provided for herein. 



('80 Code, § 77.06) (Ord. 6-76, passed 4-26-76; Am. Ord. 22-79, passed
10-29-79; Am. Ord. 24-86, passed 12-15-86; Am. Ord. 16-94, passed 10-24-94) 
Penalty, see § 77.99



§ 77.07  SPEED LIMITED TO 35 MILES PER HOUR ON THE ROADS OF THE VILLAGE.



   Except as provided in § 77.06 of this chapter, the speed limit for all
of the roads of the village shall be 35 miles per hour, unless otherwise
posted.



('80 Code, § 77.07) (Ord. 24-86, passed 12-15-86)  Penalty, see § 77.99



   MISCELLANEOUS REGULATIONS



§ 77.10  LITTER OR FOREIGN MATTER FROM CONSTRUCTION SITES ON PUBLIC
ROADWAYS, STREETS OR OTHER PUBLIC PLACES.



   (A)   No person shall operate on any public roadway, street or other
public place a vehicle with mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign
matter on its wheels or other parts if the operation results in the
depositing or tracking of such mud, dirt, substances, litter or foreign
matter on any roadway, street or other public place. No person being owner of
real property and/or a prime contractor in charge of a construction site
shall maintain such property or construction site so that vehicles upon the
property or construction site pick up mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or
foreign matter on the wheels or other parts and deposit or track the mud,
dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter onto any public roadway,
street or other public place.



   (B)   No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle
within the village unless such vehicle is so constructed and loaded as to
prevent any load, contents or litter from being thrown or deposited upon any
public roadway, street or other public place.  No person being the owner,
driver or other person in charge of a vehicle hauling excavated material,
construction or building materials, or other materials within the village
shall permit any part of such material to fall or drop or be blown therefrom
on a public roadway, street or other public place.  When a vehicle carries
trash, sawdust, ashes, cinders, sand, earth, lime, manure or other substance
liable to be blown away, the owner, driver and/any other person in charge
thereof shall, before driving or operating it on any public roadway, street
or other public place, cause such substance or substances to be completely
covered with a canvas or other substantial covering in such manner that the
same cannot fall or be blown from such vehicle.



   (C)   No person shall operate any truck or other vehicle, including
those used for hauling earth- moving and any other equipment, or that has
accumulated any mud, dirt, litter or any other debris that is liable to be
blown or otherwise dislodged during operation onto any roadway, street or
other public place.  The owner, driver or person in charge of such truck or
other vehicle shall, before operating it on any roadway, street or other
public place, cause such accumulated mud, dirt, litter or debris to be
removed or shall cover such portions of the truck or vehicle with a canvas or
other substantial covering so that such accumulated material cannot be blown
or otherwise dislodged during operation onto any roadway, street or other
public place.



   (D)   Where mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter
has been tracked or deposited on any roadway, street or other public place in
violation of divisions (A), (B) or (C) of this section of this code, the City
Manager is authorized to cause such mud, dirt, substances, litter or foreign
matter to be cleaned from such roadway, street or other public place and to
charge the cost thereof to person or persons responsible.  The term
RESPONSIBLE PERSON as used in this section shall mean the driver of the
vehicle which deposited or tracked the mud, dirt, substances, litter or
foreign matter on the street and/or the driver's employer or the owner of the
real property and/or prime contractor in charge of a construction site from
where the deposited or tracked mud, dirt, substances, litter or foreign
matter on the roadway, street or other public place originated.  Each day
that a violation of divisions (A), (B) or (C) of this section is found shall
be a separate offense.



(Ord. 06-94, passed 4-25-94)  Penalty, see § 77.99



§ 77.11  UNLAWFUL TO OPERATE A MOTOR VEHICLE IN CERTAIN PLACES.



   (A)   Definitions.  For purposes of this section, the following
words shall have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.



      ANOTHER.  Any owner, holder, lessee, occupier or the person in
charge of real and personal property.



      MOTOR VEHICLE.  Motor bikes, motorcycles, motor scooters,
go-carts, snowmobiles, and automobiles and all other vehicles which are
motor-propelled.



      PERSONAL PROPERTY.  All such property and shall include shrubs
and growing materials located in Indian Hill, and located in buildings or
enclosures on property outside Indian Hill but owned by Indian Hill.



      REAL  PROPERTY.  All such property and shall include buildings
and improvements thereon located in Indian Hill and located outside Indian
Hill but owned by Indian Hill.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a
motor vehicle on any bridle path, hiking trail, nature area, or other open
space devoted to such purposes or on any real property of another, except on
roads or areas specifically provided for motor vehicular traffic, except upon
the prior, express consent of the owner.  This section shall not be
applicable to police or fire vehicles or vehicles of the service department
of the village.



('80 Code, § 77.11) (Ord. 35-71, passed 10-25-71; Am. Ord. 22-79, passed
10-29-79)  Penalty, see § 77.99



§ 77.12  SPINNING WHEELS UNLAWFUL.



   No person shall place a vehicle in motion from a position of rest, or
accelerate a moving vehicle from a lesser speed to a greater speed, in such a
manner as to create excessive and unnecessary noise or so as to deposit
portions of the tires of the vehicle on the surface of the street, from the
spinning of tires against the pavement or materials thereon or from the high
number of revolutions of the moving parts of the engine while the vehicle is
in low or intermediate gear or gear range, or from any other cause whatsoever.



('80 Code, § 77.12) (Ord. 9-59, passed 5-26-59; Am. Ord. 22-79, passed
10-29-79)  Penalty, see § 77.99



§ 77.13  ESTABLISHMENT OF FIRE LANES.



   (A)   Fire lanes referred to in Section F.M. 3-09 of the Ohio Fire
Code, as incorporated into Ordinance No. 9-69 (See § 93.01) are established
as follows.  On private property devoted to public use, when parking of
motor vehicles may interfere with the ingress or egress of fire or police
department emergency equipment for the protection and safety of persons and
property, the City Manager has the power to designate fire lanes on private
property devoted to public use for the purpose of providing access for police
and fire department emergency equipment, and shall cause to be erected signs
stating:  No parking or standing, fire lanes, tow away zone. These signs
shall be erected at such places as indicated on a map on file in the office
of the City Manager, as the same may be revised from time to time.  This map
is incorporated into this section as if fully reproduced herein.



   (B)   Parking of motor vehicles within the designated fire lanes is
prohibited at all times.  When a police officer finds an unattended vehicle
parked within  the  fire  lane, thereby  constituting  a  possible
threat to the safety and protection of persons or property, he may cause the
removal of the vehicle.



('80 Code, § 77.13) (Ord. 30-75, passed  11-24-75; Am. Ord. 22-79, passed
10-29-79)  Penalty, see § 77.99



§ 77.14  UNLAWFUL TO OPERATE THROUGH COMMERCIAL VEHICLES IN CERTAIN PLACES.



   Except when delivering or picking up materials or merchandise, or
operating for the purpose of installing, servicing and maintaining utilities,
commercial vehicles shall not operate on streets or parts of streets within
the village.  However, the foregoing restriction does not apply to Drake
Road north of Indian Hill Road, Indian Hill Road, Loveland-Madeira Road,
Miami Road, Muchmore Road, Shawnee Run Road from Drake Road to the western
corporation line, and Remington Road.  Each person operating a commercial
vehicle on streets or parts of streets not excepted herein shall be subject
to the penalties provided in § 77.99.



(Ord. 08-00, passed 5-22-00)



   PARADES AND PROCESSIONS



§ 77.20  PERMIT.



   It shall be unlawful to conduct any parade, procession, or other mass
gathering, except funeral processions, in or on any street, alley or other
public way, place, or property in the village, unless a permit therefor is
first obtained from the City Manager, or from the Assistant City Manager, in
his absence, or from the Chief of Police in the absence of both the City
Manager and the Assistant City Manager.



('80 Code, § 77.20) (Ord. 19-80, passed 10-28-80) Penalty, see § 77.99



§ 77.21  APPLICATION; BOND; TRAFFIC CONTROL.



   (A)   Application for permits must be submitted to the Chief of
Police not later than 48 hours before the proposed parade, procession, or
mass gathering is to occur.  The application must include the following:



      (1)   The name and address of the person or organization
sponsoring the parade, procession, or mass gathering, with a telephone number
for the individual responsible for arrangements, as designated by the sponsor.



      (2)   The exact route proposed to be used by the participants,
or the place where the mass gathering is to occur, as appropriate.



      (3)   The date and times of commencement and termination for
the activity being proposed.



   (B)   The sponsor's agreement to assume financial responsibility for
any loss, damage, or liability sustained by public or private property as a
result of the activity as well as for all costs associated with the orderly
supervision thereof, together with a bond not to exceed the amount of $500,
conditioned to indemnify the village or any resident thereof for any loss,
damage, or liability incurred or caused by the conduct of this activity.



   (C)   The sponsor's agreement to hire as many personnel trained in
traffic control procedures, who must be off-duty police personnel, as the
village shall require pursuant to § 77.22 hereof, to maintain adequate
traffic control throughout the activity, unless the sponsor can demonstrate
the inability to pay for the personnel. 



('80 Code, § 77.21) (Ord. 19-80, passed 10-28-80)



§ 77.22  REVIEW; MODIFICATIONS.



   It shall be the duty of the City Manager to submit the application to
the Chief of Police and the Chief of the Fire Department for review.  The
City Manager, Chief of Police, and Chief of the Fire Department shall review
the application with particular reference to the following areas of
consideration and shall, if necessary, recommend appropriate modifications to
the applicant as soon as it is possible to do so:



   (A)   The state and condition of the streets and roads on the
proposed route, or necessary for access to the proposed site, as appropriate,
considering particularly the availability of parking at and near the proposed
site, and with respect to passability of the road for through traffic in the
event that roadside parking is necessary;



   (B)   The number of participants, including vehicles, who will be
present;



   (C)   The number of police and other personnel who may be deemed
necessary for traffic control;



   (D)   The anticipated traffic load on the village streets at the
likely time of the proposed activity, particularly in the case where the
activity is to be scheduled on or near a holiday.



('80 Code, § 77.22) (Ord. 19-80, passed 10-28-80)



§ 77.23  ISSUANCE.



   As soon as possible after the application has been submitted the
aforesaid review shall be completed and the permit shall be issued unless the
applicant does not agree to adopt any reasonable modifications requested by
the village pursuant to the provisions of § 77.22. 



('80 Code, § 77.23) (Ord. 19-80, passed 10-28-80)



§ 77.99  PENALTY.



   Whoever shall be found guilty of a violation of any of the provisions
of any section of Title VII shall, unless any different penalty is prescribed
in that section, be fined not more than $150.



('80 Code, § 77.99) (Ord.22-79, passed10-29-79; Am. Ord. 22-07, passed
12-17-07; Am. Ord. 03-08, passed 1-28-08)

CHAPTER 90:  ALARM SYSTEMS



Section



   90.01   Installation in Police Department approved



   90.02   Definitions



   90.03   License required to engage in alarm business



   90.04   Employees must be licensed with the Police Department



   90.05   Property owner needs permit for installation of alarm system



   90.06   Alarms connected to telephones prohibited



   90.07   Licenses and permits



   90.08   False alarms



   90.09   Filing of rates and charges



   90.99   Penalty



§ 90.01  INSTALLATION IN POLICE DEPARTMENT APPROVED.



   The installation in the Police Department of components of burglary and
other emergency alarm systems serving residences and other buildings in the
village is approved and authorized subject to the terms and conditions of
this chapter. 



('80 Code, § 95.01) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)



§ 90.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall
have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.



   ALARM AGENT.



      (1)   Any person who is employed by an alarm business, either
directly or indirectly, whose duties include any of the following: selling,
maintaining, leasing, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, or
installing on or in any building, structure, or facility, any alarm system.



      (2)   EXEMPTION.  The provisions of this section do not
include a person who engages in the manufacture or sale of an alarm system
from a fixed location and who neither visits the location where the alarm
system is to be installed, nor designs the scheme for physical location and
installation of the alarm system in a specific location.



   ALARM BUSINESS.  The business by any individual, partnership,
corporation, or other entity of:  selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing,
repairing, altering, replacing, moving, or installing any alarm system in
residences and other structures.



   ALARM SYSTEM.  Any mechanical, radio, or electrical device which is
designed or used for the detection of an unauthorized entry into and/or for
the detection of fire or other emergency situation within a building, or for
alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building or
both; and which emits a sound or transmits a signal when activated.



   FALSE ALARM.  An alarm signal necessitating response by the Police
Department where an emergency situation does not exist.



   LICENSEE.  Any person, firm, partnership, association, or corporation
who, or which, shall be granted a license as provided herein, and his or its
employees, agents, and representatives.



   PROPRIETOR ALARM.  An alarm which is not serviced by an alarm business.



   PERMITTEE.  One who holds a valid permit as herein provided. 



('80 Code, § 95.02) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)



§ 90.03  LICENSE REQUIRED TO ENGAGE IN ALARM BUSINESS.



   It shall be unlawful for any individual or business entity to engage in
the alarm business in residences within the corporate limits of the village
without first obtaining a license at the police department. 



('80 Code, § 95.03) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.04  EMPLOYEES MUST BE LICENSED WITH THE POLICE DEPARTMENT.



   It shall be unlawful for any individual or business entity to engage in
the alarm business in the village through the use of any employee not
previously licensed with the Police Department in accordance with § 90.07. 



('80 Code, § 95.04) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.05  PROPERTY OWNER NEEDS PERMIT FOR INSTALLATION OF ALARM SYSTEM.



   No burglary or other emergency alarm system shall be installed in any
residence or other building in this village until a permit for the
installation is issued to the property owner.



('80 Code, § 95.05) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.06  ALARMS CONNECTED TO TELEPHONES PROHIBITED.



   No person, firm, or corporation shall use or cause to be used any alarm
system which automatically selects or dials a telephone or telephone trunk
line used by or assigned to the village for telephone service, which system
then transmits over the line a report or alarm concerning a burglary, fire,
or other police emergency, except that any installed prior to April 25, 1977
will not be affected, and that licenses shall be issued to such person, firm,
partnership, association, or corporation, limited to those alarms installed
as of that date.



('80 Code, § 95.06) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.07  LICENSES AND PERMITS.



   (A)   Licenses.



      (1)   Alarm business license.  No person shall engage in,
conduct, or carry on an alarm business without first applying for and
receiving an alarm business license therefor in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter.



      (2)   Alarm agent license.  No person shall engage in,
conduct, or operate as an alarm agent without first applying for and
receiving an alarm agent license therefor in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter.



      (3)   In addition, the following information will also be
required:



         (a)   Name and address of applicant.



         (b)   Full local address of applicant.



         (c)   The name, address, and other necessary pertinent
information of all alarm agents sought to be used in connection with any
installation made in the village.



   (B)   The Police Chief may dispense with the investigation upon
being furnished with an authenticated copy of a current license issued by
another governmental agency located in the county. The permit shall be denied
by the Police Chief if:



      (1)   The character or reputation of the applicant is
determined to be inimical to the safety or general welfare of the community;
or



      (2)   The applicant, his employee, or agent has knowingly made
false, misleading, or fraudulent statements of a material fact in the
application for a license; or



      (3)   The applicant has had a similar type license previously
revoked for a good cause.



   (C)   Alarm system permit.  No person shall possess or use an alarm
system without first applying for and receiving an alarm permit therefor in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.  In addition, the following
information will also be requested:



      (1)   Name and address of property owner.



      (2)   The location of all alarmed doors, windows, pressure
pads, or other devices which would trigger the alarm.



      (3)   The location of all alarm consoles and operational
instructions for each alarm location.



      (4)   The name of the company installing the system.



      (5)   An agreement to deposit a key to the protected building
and a key to the alarm system used in the residence or protected building,
and to provide access to the main control panel.



      (6)   Agreement to use an assigned code number of the
installation.



   (D)   The record in division (C) shall be privileged and not
available for public inspection.  No employee of the village shall divulge
any information obtained in connection with the permit application.



('80 Code, § 95.07) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.08  FALSE ALARMS.



   (A)   The Chief of Police shall keep an accurate record of all false
alarms.



   (B)   An alarm system shall constitute a public nuisance if it
activates more than three false alarms in any 360-day period.  Each false
alarm record will be eliminated on the 360th day after that false alarm. 



   (C)   When the holder of a permit for an alarm system activates more
than three false alarms in a 360 day period, a $15 responding fee shall be
charged to that holder for each of the fourth and fifth false alarms.



   (D)   For the sixth false alarm in a 360- day period a $30
responding fee shall be charged to the holder.



   (E)   The seventh false alarm of the alarm of a holder in a 360-day
period constitutes an offense and will result in the issuance of a citation
to Mayor's Court.



   (F)   Subscribers shall keep their alarm system in good repair.



   (G)   Subscribers and permittees shall notify the Police Department
prior to any service, test, repair, maintenance, adjustment, alteration, or
installation which might activate a false alarm.



   (H)   Each false alarm in excess of three in any 360-day period
shall constitute a separate responding fee.



      (1)   For the first false alarm within a 360-day period, the
Police Department will advise the permittee in writing that the false alarm
has occurred and recommend that appropriate steps be taken to prevent future
occurrences.



      (2)   Upon the occurrence of a second false alarm within a
360-day period, the Police Department will send a second written
communication to the permittee advising of the false alarm and of the
consequence of continued false alarms.



      (3)   Upon the occurrence of the third false alarm in a
360-day period, the Police Department will cause a Police Officer to contact
the permittee to attempt to correct the situation and to advise the permittee
that a fourth false alarm within a 360-day period will result in a fee being
imposed.



      (4)   Upon the occurrence of the fourth, fifth and sixth false
alarms, the Police Department will serve the permittee an invoice for the
responding fee specified in divisions (C) or (D) of this section.



      (5)   Upon the occurrence of the seventh false alarm, the
Police Department shall issue a citation to the permittee as specified in
division (E) of this section.



   (I)   The first false alarm of an alarm system for which there is no
valid permit outstanding shall constitute a responding fee being levied as
prescribed in division (C) of this section.



('80 Code, § 95.08) (Ord. 13-77, passed 4-25-77; Am. Ord. 14-89, passed
6-19-89)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.09  FILING OF RATES AND CHARGES.



   Beginning on August 1, 1980, and thereafter, no alarm business shall
conduct its business within the village without having filed with the City
Manager a schedule of rates and charges.  The alarm business license, as
provided for in § 90.07 hereof, of any such alarm business failing to file a
schedule of rates and charges on or before August 1, 1980 shall be revoked. 
All applicants for alarm business license shall file with the Manager a
schedule of rates and charges for its services before any alarm business
license shall be issued.  At any time there is to be a change in rates and
charges of an alarm business for services provided within the village, the
alarm business shall file a new schedule of rates and charges reflecting such
changes to be effective on 30 days notice.  No alarm business engaging in
that business in the village from and after August 1, 1980 shall charge for
the services it provides other than those rates and charges which are on file
with the Manager.  So long as any alarm business utilizes the premises of
the Indian Hill Rangers, the City Manager, or Council may, from time to time,
require such supporting data and information as he shall determine is
appropriate to demonstrate the reasonableness of all rates and charges to be
filed by an alarm business with rates and charges on file. 



('80 Code, § 95.09) (Ord. 12-80, passed 6-23-80)  Penalty, see § 90.99



§ 90.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not more than $50 for each offense. A person so
fined may pay the $50 within 168 hours of the date of the citation without
court appearance or may appear in court at the time and place indicated in
the citation.



('80 Code, § 95.99) (Am. Ord. 14-89, passed 6-19- 89)



CHAPTER 91:  ANIMALS



Section
