GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 94.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall
have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.



   AUTOMOBILE PARTS.   Any portion or part of any motor-driven vehicle as
detached from the vehicle as a whole.



   CITY MANAGER.   The City Manager of the Village of Indian Hill, or
City Manager's designee.



   CONSTRUCTION SITE.   The  location of any site preparation, assembly,
erection, substantial repair, alteration, or similar action, for or of public
or private rights-of-way, structures, utilities or similar property
demolition.



   CONSTRUCTION TOOLS AND EQUIPMENT.   Items used by workers at a
construction site, including but not limited to: material-handling,
earth-moving and digging equipment, power tools, generators, air compressors,
hand tools, and radios and other sound-generating equipment.



   DWELLING.   A single structure providing complete, independent living
facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for
living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation.



   EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS.   Those portions of a building which are
exposed to public view and the open space of any premises outside of any
building.



   LITTER.   Includes any garbage, waste, rubbish, ashes, cans, bottles,
wire, paper, plastic, metal, cartons, boxes, wagons, furniture, glass, oil of
an unsightly or unsanitary nature, or anything else of an unsightly or
unsanitary nature.



   MOTOR VEHICLE IN AN INOPERATIVE CONDITION.  Any style or type of
motor-driven vehicle used or useful for the conveyance of persons or property
which is unable to move under its own power due to defective or missing
parts, and which has remained in such condition for a period not less than
ten consecutive days.



   NEW OR USED BUILDING MATERIALS.  Any materials such as wood, stone,
brick, cement blocks, or any composition or combination thereof used or
useful in the construction of any building, structure of driveway, including
materials which have been used previously for such construction by the same
person or other persons.



   NOXIOUS WEEDS.  Weeds which may from time to time be identified as
noxious by the Ohio State University Extension Service, including but not
limited to: Wild Mustard, Musk thistle (Nodding thistle), Oxeye Daisy, Canada
thistle, Poison Hemlock, Wild Carrot (Queen Annes Lace), Purple Loosestrife,
wild parsnip, Mile-a-Minute Weed, Russian Thistle, Cressleaf Groundsel,
Shattercane, Johnsongrass, and Grapevines (abandoned).



   NUISANCE.  That which is defined by the statutes of the state of Ohio
and declared thereby to be a nuisance, and also conditions dangerous to human
life or detrimental to the health of persons on or near the premises where
conditions exist, and where the conditions are perilous by active and
negligent operation thereof, and unsanitary conditions or anything offensive
to the senses of a person of ordinary sensibilities or dangerous to health.



   OCCUPANT. Any person living in a dwelling structure or having actual
possession of said dwelling structure.



   OWNER.  Any person, who, alone or jointly or severally with others,
shall have legal title to any premises, with or without the actual possession
thereof; or shall have charge, care or control as owner or agent of the
owner; or as executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or guardian of an
estate, or as a mortgagee in possession.



   PERSON.  Any individual, corporation, association, partnership,
trustee, lessee, agent or assignee.



   PREMISES.  A lot, plot, or parcel of land, including the buildings or
structures thereon within the corporate limits of the Village.



   SCRAP METAL.  Pieces of or parts of steel, iron, tin, zinc, copper,
aluminum, or any alloy thereof, whether covered with porcelain or other
material, whether intact or in parts, which has served its usefulness in its
original form and can no longer be used or useful for its originally intended
purpose.



   STRUCTURE.  Anything constructed or erected, the use of which is the
main purpose for the premises, and/or accessory or incidental to and
associated with the principal use of the premises, and which requires
location on the ground or attachment to something having a location on the
ground.



   TENANT.  A person, corporation, partnership or group, whether or not
the legal owner of record, occupying a building or portion thereof.



   UNLICENSED MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAILERS.  Any style or type of motor
vehicle or any trailer of any kind or type without current license plates.



   VILLAGE.  The city of the Village of Indian Hill.



('80 Code, § 91.01) (Ord. 14-45, passed 11-27-45; Am. Ord. 39-66, passed
11-29-66; Am. Ord. 11-92, passed 9-28-92; Am. Ord. 03-06, passed 1-30-06; Am.
Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



§ 94.02  PROHIBITIONS CONCERNING REFUSE, RUBBISH, AND MOTOR VEHICLES.



   (A)   Except as provided in § 94.04, it shall be unlawful and is
declared to be a nuisance for any person to store, place, or allow to remain
new or used building materials, scrap metal, refuse, or rubbish, on any
premises within the corporate limits of the village, other than in completely
enclosed buildings.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful and is declared to be a nuisance for any
person to store, place or allow to remain motor vehicles in an inoperative
condition or unlicensed motor vehicles and trailers, or automobile parts on
any premises other than in completely enclosed buildings.



('80 Code, § 91.02) (Ord. 39-66, passed 11-29-66; Am. Ord. 11-92, passed
9-28-92; Am. Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.03  ORDER FOR REMOVAL.



   (A)   In the event of a violation of § 94.02, the City Manager
shall give notice to the owner, occupant, or person having charge of the
premises upon which the violation occurs to cease such violation. This notice
shall be in writing  and shall be served upon the owner, occupant, or person
having charge of the premises either personally by a member of the Police
Department or at the usual place of residency of such owner, occupant, or
person having charge of such premises by registered or certified mail
addressed to such person's last place of residence.



   (B)   If the person served with the notice, as provided in division
(A) fails to cause such violation to cease within ten days of the date upon
which the notice was issued, except as provided in division (C), he or she
shall be subject to the penalty provided in § 94.99, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed upon each and every day during or on which the
violation occurs or continues beyond the ten day period.  However, no
additional notice of violation is required to be given for the subsequent
days.



   (C)   If the person served with the notice, as provided in division
(A), has been found in violation of § 94.02 of the Code of Ordinances at any
time during the five years prior to the date of the current notice, he or she
shall be deemed to be in immediate violation and shall not be granted an
additional ten days to cause such violation to cease.  He or she shall be
immediately subject to the penalty provided in § 94.99, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed upon each and every day during or on which
the violation occurs or continues beyond the original date of notice,
provided, however, that no additional notice of violation is required to be
given for the subsequent days.



('80 Code, § 91.03)  (Ord. 39-66, passed 11-29-66; Am. Ord. 07-97, passed
5-27-97; Am. Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



§ 94.04  EXCEPTIONS.



   Notwithstanding the provisions of § 94.02, it shall be lawful for any
person to place or store new or used building materials on any premises when
such materials are to be used by the purchaser or owner in later construction
on the same premises owned or controlled by such person; provided thatsuch
materials shall not remain on the premises for a period of more than 30 days
unless the construction or erection plan for the use of the materials has
commenced; and provided further that such materials are used or consumed in
the construction or removed from the premises within the period of four
months from the time the materials are first placed on the premises.  It
shall be unlawful for any person or persons to move any materials so stored
or placed to another location within the village for the purpose of avoiding
the intent of this section, except that any such materials may be moved to
another premises when the same have been sold to a bona fide purchaser for
value for such purchaser's own use.



('80 Code, § 91.04) (Ord. 39-66, passed 11-29-66; Am. Ord. 21-07, passed
12-17-07)



§ 94.05  DISPOSAL OF LITTER ON PUBLIC STREETS AND UPON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE
PROPERTY.



   It shall be unlawful to discard or dispose of litter upon the public
highways or right-of-ways of the village, or upon any exterior property areas
in the village.



('80 Code, § 91.05) (Ord. 12-45, passed 10-30-45; Am. Ord. 21-07, passed
12-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



CONSTRUCTION NOISE NUISANCES



§ 94.10  PURPOSE.



   The purpose of this section is to limit excessive construction noise
that interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life, property, recreation
or conduct of business as defined and described in this section.



(Ord. 03-06, passed 1-30-06)



§ 94.11  LIMITATIONS ON USE OF CONSTRUCTION TOOLS AND EQUIPMENT.



   (A)   Use of construction tools and equipment.  Except as provided
in division (C) through (G) of this section, no person may use construction
tools and equipment except between 7:30 a.m. and 7:30 p.m. Monday through
Friday and between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on Saturdays; provided, however,
that such tools and equipment shall not be used at any time on the following
federal holidays: New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day,
Thanksgiving, and Christmas.



   (B)   Emergencies.  The limitations stated in division (A) of this
section shall not apply in any situation which requires heavy equipment or
other tools in emergencies to assist or avoid a problem related to health or
to safety of persons or property, or to sewer, water, power, utility, or
telephone interruptions.



   (C)   Work by public agencies.  The limitations stated in division
(A) of this section may be waived by the City Manager for work undertaken by
any public body or agency for the benefit of the public. The City Manager may
attach to any such waiver all conditions he or she deems necessary to protect
the public health, safety, or welfare.



   (D)   Farming and other agricultural activities.  The prohibitions
stated in division (A) of this section shall not be construed to apply to any
bona fide farming or agricultural activity.



   (E)   Routine landscaping and other yard and golf course maintenance
activities.  The prohibitions stated in division (A) of this section shall
not  be construed to apply to any routine landscaping and other yard and
golf course maintenance activities, including snow removal, performed either
by a resident or property owner, or under a maintenance agreement with a
resident or property owner.



   (F)   Use of power tools for interior work by resident or property
owner.  The prohibitions stated in division (A) of this section shall not 
be construed to apply to the use of power tools for home repairs and/or
hobbies by a resident or property owner within the interior of their
residence, garage, or other accessory structure.



   (G)   Waiver. 



      (1)   The prohibitions stated in division (A) of this section
may be waived by the City Manager in the case of exceptional circumstances;
provided, however, that no such waiver shall be granted unless the City
Manager finds that:



         (a)   The party seeking the waiver will suffer a
significant hardship unless the waiver is granted; and



         (b)   The granting of a waiver will not cause a
substantial or undue adverse impact upon adjacent property or upon the public
health, safety and welfare.



      (2)   The City Manager may attach to such waiver all
conditions he or she deems necessary to protect the public health, safety or
welfare.



(Ord. 03-06, passed 1-30-06)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.12  PERMITS FOR WAIVERS.



   (A)   Applications for a permit for a waiver from the prohibitions
designated in § 94.11 on the basis of undue hardship and/or practical
difficulty may be made to the City Manager. A letter of request containing
the basis for the request must accompany each application. The relief
requested may be granted upon a good and sufficient finding by the City
Manager that the specific circumstances set forth in the waiver request
satisfy the conditions set forth in § 94.11(G)(1) and (2).



   (B)   If granted, the permit shall be in writing and contain all
conditions upon which such permit is granted, including, but not limited to,
the effective dates, any time-of-day, location, sound-pressure-level, or
equipment limitations. The City Manager may prescribe any reasonable
conditions or requirements deemed necessary to minimize adverse effects upon
the community or the surrounding area.



   (C)   In the event the City Manager denies an application for a
permit for waiver from the noise restrictions designated in this subchapter,
or grants relief under conditions the applicant finds unacceptable, the
affected party may appeal the decision to the City Council by filing a
written letter with the City Manager within ten calendar days after receiving
notice of the City Manager's decision. The appeal letter must specifically
state each and every point of contention with the City Manager's
determination the City Manager shall immediately cause the appeal to be
placed on the next regular meeting agenda of the City Council for discussion
and action. When considering an appeal of the City Manager's determination,
the City Council shall consider the intent contained in this section, the
City Manager's reasons for denying a permit or applying conditions, the
applicant's points raised in the letter of appeal, and relevant surrounding
facts.



(Ord. 03-06, passed 1-30-06)



§ 94.13  ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   Responsible violators. The persons responsible for violations
of § 94.11 are identified as follows:



      (1)   At private residences.  Any adult resident present at
the time of the offense, and any adult guest or adult trespasser with the
ability to control the use of construction tools and equipment at the time of
the offense when no adult resident is present at the time of the offense.



      (2)   At nonresidential locations.  Any property owner,
director, operator, manager, employee in charge, and all persons in control
or possession of the construction tools and equipment at the time of the
offense.



      (3)   At any location with unattended construction tools and
equipment.  Any person who leaves unattended any construction tools and
equipment, which thereafter continue to operate during the time prohibited by
this section.



   (B)   Warning.  Any person or persons violating this subchapter
shall first be warned of the unlawfulness of such activity and be given a
reasonable opportunity to discontinue such activity prior to being subject to
further enforcement action. Only one warning shall be issued per occurrence.
Not more than one warning shall be necessary during any 24-hour period for
any construction site.



   (C)   Enforcement remedies.  In the event that the violation is not
abated as ordered and within the time specified, the village may abate such
violation by one or more of the methods listed below. Each time the violation
is not abated as directed shall be considered a separate violation.



      (1)   Issuance of a citation, subject to the applicable fines
set forth in § 94.99(D).



      (2)   Undertaking a public abatement of the violation and
assessment of costs thereof.



      (3)   Remedied by means of a civil court proceeding or any
other lawful process pursuant to the Ohio Revised Code.



(Ord. 03-06, passed 1-30-06)



   WEEDS



§ 94.15  NOTICE TO OWNER TO CUT NOXIOUS WEEDS; REMOVE LITTER; SERVICE.



   (A)   Upon a finding by the City Manager that noxious weeds are
growing on premises, the City Manager shall cause a written notice to be
served upon the owner, lessee, agent, or tenant having charge of such
premises, notifying him or her that noxious weeds are growing on such
premises and that they must be cut and destroyed within five days after the
service of such notice.



   (B)   Upon a finding by the City Manager that litter has been placed
on premises, and has not been removed, and constitutes a detriment to public
health, the City Manager shall cause a written notice to be served upon the
owner and, if different, upon the lessee, agent, or tenant having charge of
the littered premises, notifying him that litter is on the premises, and that
it must be collected and removed within 15 days after the service of the
notice.



   (C)   If the person served with the notice, as provided in division
(A) of this section, has been found in violation of this § 94.15 at any time
during the five years prior to the date of the current notice, he or she
shall be deemed to be in immediate violation and shall not be granted an
additional five/fifteen days to cause such violation to cease. He or she
shall be immediately subject to the penalty provided in § 94.99, and a
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each and every day during or
on which the violation occurs or continues beyond the original date of
notice, provided, however, that no additional notice of violation is required
to be given for the subsequent days.



   (D)   If the owner or other person having charge of the premises is
a nonresident of the village whose address is known, the notice shall be sent
to his address by certified mail. If the address of the owner or other person
having charge of the premises is unknown it is sufficient to publish the
notice once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county.



   (E)   In addition to the power and authority granted in division
(B), the City Manager is authorized, upon his or her own motion, with or
without written notice, to cause the cutting and destruction of noxious weeds
in accordance with the procedures set forth in R.C. § 731.51.



('80 Code, § 91.15) (R.C. § 731.51) (Ord. 26-52, passed 12-5-52; Am. Ord.
21-07, passed 12-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.16  FEES FOR SERVICE AND RETURN.



   A police officer or the City Manager, or a deputy, may make service and
return of the notice provided for in § 94.15 and the fees therefor shall be
the same as are allowed for service and return of summons in civil cases
before a magistrate. 



('80 Code, § 91.16) (R.C.§ 731.52)  (Am. Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



§ 94.17  PROCEDURE WHEN OWNER FAILS TO COMPLY WITH NOTICE.



   If the owner, lessee, agent, or tenant having charge of  the lands
mentioned in § 94.15 fails to comply with the notice required by such
section, the City Manager  shall cause such noxious weeds to be cut and
destroyed or such litter to be removed and may employ the necessary labor to
perform such task.  All expenses incurred, when approved by the Council,
shall be paid out of any money in the treasury of the village not otherwise
appropriated.



(R.C. § 731.53)  ('80 Code, § 91.17)  (Am. Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07) 
Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.18  WRITTEN RETURN TO COUNTY AUDITOR; AMOUNT A LIEN UPON PROPERTY.



   The Council shall make a written return to the County Auditor of its
action under §§ 94.15 through 94.17, with a statement of the charges for
its services, the amount paid for the performing of such labor, the fees of
the officers who made the service of the notice and return, and a proper
description of the premises.  Such amounts, when allowed, shall be entered
upon the tax duplicate, shall be a lien upon such lands from the date of the
entry, and shall be collected as other taxes and returned to the village with
the general fund.



(R.C. § 731.54)  ('80 Code, § 91.18)  (Am. Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



PROPERTY MAINTENANCE



§ 94.21  RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS OR OCCUPANTS.



   The owner or occupant of any dwelling shall be responsible for
maintaining the dwelling, in a clean and sanitary condition.



(Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.22  GENERAL MAINTENANCE REQUIREMENTS.



   (A)   All dwellings, and all parts thereof, shall be maintained in
good repair, and free from health, accident and fire hazards.



   (B)   All accessory structures, equipment and facilities appurtenant
to a dwelling structure shall be maintained in good repair and free from
health, accident and fire hazards and in a sanitary condition, or shall be
removed from the premises.



(Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.23  EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS.



   No owner, agent or occupant of any premises shall maintain or permit to
be maintained at or on such premises any condition which creates a fire,
safety or health hazard; or which is a nuisance; including, but not limited
to: broken or dilapidated fences, walls or other structures.



(Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)  Penalty, see § 94.99



§ 94.24  NON-APPLICABILITY TO FARMING AND OTHER AGRICULTURAL ACTIVITIES.



   The maintenance responsibilities and requirements set forth in § 94.23
shall not be construed to apply to any bona fide farming or agricultural
activity.



(Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



§ 94.25  NOTICE OF VIOLATION.



   Whenever the City Manager or his or her authorized representative
determines that there has been a violation of any provision of §§ 94.21
through 94.23, he or she shall give notice of such violation to the person
responsible therefor and order compliance with these regulations as
hereinafter provided. Such notice shall:



   (A)   Be put in writing on an appropriate form;



   (B)   Include a list of violations, referring to the section or
sections of these regulations that have been violated, and order remedial
action which, if taken, will effect compliance with these regulations;



   (C)   Specify a reasonable time for performance;



   (D)   Be served on the owner, agent, or occupant in person. However,
this notice and order shall be deemed to be properly served upon the owner,
agent or occupant if a copy thereof is sent by registered or certified mail
to the person's last known mailing address, residence, or place of business,
and/or a copy is posted in a conspicuous place in or on the dwelling affected.



(Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



§ 94.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person who violates or fails to comply with any of the
notices or cease and desist provisions of §§ 94.02 through 94.04 shall be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine
of not more than $150. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each
day beyond the ten day cure period upon which a violation occurs or continues.



   (B)   Any person who violates § 94.05 shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree for each an every offense and upon
conviction shall be subject to a fine or penalty of not more than $250.



   (C)   (1)   Except as provided in division (C)(2) or (C)(3) of
this section, any person violating any of the provisions of § 94.11 shall be
guilty of a minor misdemeanor and subject to a fine or penalty of not more
than $150.



      (2)   Any person violating any of the provisions of § 94.11
for a second time during any 30-day period of time shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree and upon conviction shall be subject to a
fine or penalty of not more than $250.



      (3)   Any person violating any of the provisions of § 94.11
for a third time during any 30-day period of time shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree and upon conviction shall be subject to a
fine or penalty of not more than $500 for each offense.



   (D)   Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses
to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of
§ 94.15 shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor and on conviction shall be
subject to a fine or penalty of not more than $150 for each offense. Each and
every day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense.



   (E)   Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses
to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of, any of the provisions of
§§ 94.21 through 94.23 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree
and on conviction shall be subject to a fine or penalty of not more than $500
for each offense. Each and every day that a violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.



   (F)   The City Solicitor is authorized, upon evidence of probable
cause of violation, and to prevent future violation, to bring an action in a
court of appropriate jurisdiction to enjoin violation of the provisions
hereof.



('80 Code, § 91.99(A), (B), (C), (E))  (Am. Ord. 10-00, passed 5-22-00; Am.
Ord. 03-06, passed 1-30-06; Am. Ord. 21-07, passed 12-17-07)



CHAPTER 95:  PARKS



Section



   95.01   Parks and other green areas and preserves shall be closed
one hour after sunset



   95.02   Grand Valley Preserve regulations



   95.99   Penalty



§ 95.01  PARKS AND OTHER GREEN AREAS AND PRESERVES SHALL BE CLOSED ONE HOUR
AFTER SUNSET.



   All public parks, Green Areas, the Grand Valley Preserve,  and the
Rowe Arboretum shall be closed to the public after one hour after sunset for
each day until one hour before sunrise the next day during the year except as
provided by special permit or authorization by the City Manager.



('80 Code, § 91.20) (Ord. 22-74, passed 11-15-74; Am. Ord. 5-75, passed
2-24-75; Am. Ord. 5-80, passed 2-25-80; Am. Ord. 10-93, passed 6-21-93; Am.
Ord. 09-07, passed 5-21-07)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.02  GRAND VALLEY PRESERVE REGULATIONS.



   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to prepare and
maintain regulations related to the use of the Grand Valley Preserve by
visitors. Violations of these regulations shall be subject to the penalty
provisions set forth in § 95.99. The City Manager is further authorized to
amend said regulations, as may be necessary.



(Ord. 09-07, passed 5-21-07)  Penalty, see § 95.99



§ 95.99  PENALTY.



   Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more
than $150 for each offense.



('80 Code, § 91.99(F))  (Am. Ord. 09-07, passed 5-21-07)



CHAPTER 96:  TUBERCULOSIS CONTROL



Section



   96.01   Definitions



   96.02   Duty of physicians and heads of institutions to report



   96.03   Duty of agencies to report



   96.04   Laboratories to report



   96.05   Record to be confidential



   96.06   Duty of persons affected with tuberculosis



   96.07   Persons with tuberculosis in communicable form not to be
employed



   96.08   Duty of persons in charge of children to exclude person
known to be affected with tuberculosis



   96.09   Providing for examination of person suspected of having
tuberculosis in a communicable form



   96.10   Authority for persons affected with tuberculosis in a
communicable form to remain at home



   96.11   Removal and detention of persons affected with tuberculosis
in a communicable form



   96.12   Authority for examination of persons with known or suspected
tuberculosis



   96.13   Providing for examination of employees of hospitals,
maternity homes, infant homes, nursing homes, nursery schools and child day
care centers, and baby sitting services



   96.14   Regulations for testing school children for tuberculosis



   96.99   Penalty



§ 96.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ASSOCIATE.  A person of any age who has been in close association with
a positive reactor and may be the source of infection.



   CLINICAL CASE.  A person whose tuberculosis infection has been found
to be active by examination of x-ray films or bacteriologic specimens, in
compliance with the criteria in Diagnostic Standards and Classification of
Tuberculosis (American Lung Association).



   CONTACT.  A person of any age who has been in close association with
an active case of tuberculosis for a sufficient length of time to become
infected with M. tuberculosis by breathing the contaminated air.



   HAMILTON COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF TUBERCULOSIS CONTROL.  An interagency
department designed to coordinate all the efforts being made in tuberculosis
control in Hamilton County, through uniform policies, procedures, and program.



   HAMILTON COUNTY TUBERCULOSIS CONTROLLER.  The director of the Hamilton
County Department of Tuberculosis Control, who by approval and designation by
the Hamilton County District Health Commissioners shall act as their agent in
the control of tuberculosis.



   HEALTH COMMISSIONER.  Chief Health Officer of a district or an agent
designated by that authority.



('80 Code, § 92.01) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)



§ 96.02  DUTY OF PHYSICIANS AND HEADS OF INSTITUTIONS TO REPORT.



   (A)   It shall be the duty of every physician, or every person
practicing a healing art, to report to the Health Commissioner via the
Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis Control within 24 hours, the full
name, address, color, sex, age, marital status, occupation, last place of
employment, form of disease, bacteriological status, and medication (with
dosage) being prescribed of any person in whom a diagnosis of clinical
tuberculosis has been made.  (In the case of clinical consultants the full
name and address of the referring physician shall be included in the report).



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the director, superintendent, manager,
or a person in charge of any hospital, clinic dispensary, asylum, or
correctional institution to report to the Health Commissioner via the
Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis Control within 24 hours, the full
name, address, color, sex, age, marital status, occupation, last place of
employment, form of disease, bacteriological status, and medication (with
dosage) being prescribed, of every person diagnosed or treated therein who is
affected with clinical tuberculosis.



   (C)   Chemoprophylaxis is recommended for cases of nonclinical
disease having high personal or technical risk factor.



('80 Code, § 92.02) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.03  DUTY OF AGENCIES TO REPORT.



   It shall be the duty of the head of every convalescent or nursing home,
social agency, or similar public or private institution or organization
having knowledge of, or rendering care to a person affected with tuberculosis
to report to the Health Commissioner via the Hamilton County Department of
Tuberculosis Control within 24 hours, the full name, address, color, sex,
age, marital status, occupation, last place of employment, and other facts
relating to home conditions that may be pertinent to isolation of such
persons.



('80 Code, § 92.03) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.04  LABORATORIES TO REPORT.



   It shall be the duty of all public, private, commercial, or other
bacteriological or pathological laboratories rendering diagnostic service, to
report in writing to the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis Control
within 24 hours, the full name and such other data as may be available of
such persons whose sputum, gastric contents, or other specimens submitted for
examination, reveal the presence of tubercle bacilli or other acid fast
bacilli.  Such laboratories shall report the name and address of the
physician or of any other person or agency referring such specimens for
examination for the purpose of obtaining a clinical diagnosis.



('80 Code, § 92.04) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.05  RECORD TO BE CONFIDENTIAL.



   (A)   All reports of cases of tuberculosis made in accordance with
the provisions of the above regulations, and all records of clinical or
laboratory examinations for, or indicating the presence of, tuberculosis
shall be confidential.  Such reports and records shall not be open to
inspection by the public or by any person other than the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller, Health Commissioner of the district, or their
designates, or such other persons as may be authorized by law to inspect such
records, without the consent in writing of the person whose record it is, or
his parent, guardian, or authorized representative.



   (B)   The Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller may furnish such
information as he deems proper and necessary to a physician or institution
giving care and treatment to a person affected with tuberculosis, or to an
agency approved by the Controller, for the purpose of prevention and
treatment of the disease.  Except as provided by law, no custodian of any
report or record mentioned in the above regulations, the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller or any other person, institution, or agency having
control of, or access to such reports and records shall divulge any part
thereof so as to disclose the identity of the person to whom it relates.



('80 Code, § 92.05) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.06  DUTY OF PERSONS AFFECTED WITH TUBERCULOSIS.



   Every person affected with tuberculosis shall comply with the rules and
regulations of the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis Control and
shall not maliciously, carelessly, willfully, wantonly, or negligently cause,
contribute to, or promote the spread of such disease.



('80 Code, § 92.06) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.07  PERSONS WITH TUBERCULOSIS IN COMMUNICABLE FORM NOT TO BE EMPLOYED.



   Every person affected with tuberculosis in a communicable form is
prohibited from working without the approval of the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller or the District Health Commissioner, in a hospital,
school, shop, factory, office, other commercial establishment, as a domestic
servant, or any place in which he or she may be in close contact with other
persons.  Where such person, after being warned, refuses to observe the
rules and regulations of the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis
Control, relating to the protection of the public, the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller or the District Health Commissioner may, in his
discretion notify the employer of the condition of a person affected with the
disease.  Approval to work may only be granted to such person by the
Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller or the District Health Commissioner
where the work proposed to be done would not constitute a significant health
hazard to others.



('80 Code, § 92.07) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.08  DUTY OF PERSONS IN CHARGE OF CHILDREN TO EXCLUDE PERSON KNOWN TO
BE AFFECTED WITH TUBERCULOSIS.



   (A)   No principal, superintendent, master, teacher, or instructor
in any educational institution, or person in charge of any agency giving care
to children, and no parent, guardian, or custodian of any child or minor
shall permit such child or minor to be exposed to contact with any person
affected with tuberculosis in a communicable form, nor shall such person
permit any child or minor known by them to be affected with tuberculosis in a
communicable form to attend any public, private, or parochial educational
institution for children.  A principal, superintendent, or master, in any
educational institution or person in charge of an agency giving care to
children shall require all new employees within 90 days before their first
work day, and thereafter as determined by the District Board of Health, to
obtain a certificate from the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis
Control or a private physician, stating such employee to be free of
tuberculosis in a communicable form.  Such certificate shall, in all
instances, be based on a tuberculin skin test, chest x-ray examination if a
positive reactor or on such other clinical laboratory examinations as may be
required.  The authorities of such educational institutions shall place
their copy of such certificates on file.



   (B)   The Board, superintendent, or other persons having charge of
any public, private, or parochial educational institution for children shall
notify all pupils of grades designated by the District Health Commissioner,
and all new school enrollees, and transferees, that they are required to
furnish evidence obtained from a physician or the Hamilton County Department
of Tuberculosis Control of having had a current tuberculin skin test within
the previous 90 days.  The evidence so furnished shall also include the
results of the test. These requirements or any part thereof may be waived on
agreement by the District Health Commissioner and the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller.  Board of Education shall waive the required test
where a pupil presents a written statement from his family physician
certifying that such test is inadvisable for medical reasons, or from his
parent or guardian objecting to such test because of religious convictions.



('80 Code, § 92.08) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.09  PROVIDING FOR EXAMINATION OF PERSON SUSPECTED OF HAVING
TUBERCULOSIS IN A COMMUNICABLE FORM.



   Any person whom the District Health Commissioner or the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller has reasonable cause to suspect of having
tuberculosis in a communicable form by reason of either:



   (A)   Demonstrable contract with another person who has or has had
tuberculosis in a communicable form, or



   (B)   Evidence of tuberculosis infection in other members of a
household, or



   (C)   On receipt of notice from health departments or medical
sources in another jurisdiction that a person in the county has or is
suspected of having tuberculosis, or



   (D)   Manifestation of certain signs and symptoms suggestive of
tuberculosis shall on request of the District Health Commissioner or the
Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller, as his agent submit to such
examinations as prescribed by the District Health Commissioner or the
Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller.



('80 Code, § 92.09) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.10  AUTHORITY FOR PERSONS AFFECTED WITH TUBERCULOSIS IN A COMMUNICABLE
FORM TO REMAIN AT HOME.



   No person affected with tuberculosis in a communicable form shall be
permitted to remain at home, in a boarding home, hotel, convalescent or
nursing home, hospital, or like place, when such accommodations are deemed
inadequate for isolation by the District Health Commissioner or the Hamilton
County Tuberculosis Controller.



('80 Code, § 92.10) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.11  REMOVAL AND DETENTION OF PERSONS AFFECTED WITH TUBERCULOSIS IN A
COMMUNICABLE FORM.



   (A)   Whenever an authorized physician shall report in writing to
the Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller that a person affected with
tuberculosis in a communicable form cannot otherwise be properly isolated and
cared for, the Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller through the District
Health Commissioner may cause the removal of such person to a hospital
satisfactory to the Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller.  Such detention
shall be continued until proper arrangements for isolation and care are
otherwise provided or until the District Health Commissioner or the Hamilton
County Tuberculosis Controller determines the disease to be no longer in a
communicable form.



   (B)   Whenever a person detained in accordance with the foregoing
believes that such detention is not warranted he or his representative may
apply to the District Health Commissioner via the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller, for a hearing to be held within five days before a
board of three physicians appointed in the manner following:  Hamilton
County Tuberculosis Controller shall appoint one physician, the patient shall
select one physician, and the third shall be selected by the two first
chosen.  The members of the board may take testimony and examine the patient
and all pertinent case records. The decision of the board shall be binding on
the District Health Commissioner, the Hamilton County Tuberculosis
Controller, and the patient.



('80 Code, § 92.11) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.12  AUTHORITY FOR EXAMINATION OF PERSONS WITH KNOWN OR SUSPECTED
TUBERCULOSIS.



   (A)   The following persons, as defined in § 96.01, shall be
required by the District Health Commissioner or Hamilton County Tuberculosis
Controller to be examined for tuberculosis, which examination may be made by
the person's own physician or if so desired, it will be made at no expense to
the individual by the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis Control.



      (1)   SUSPECT.



      (2)   CONTACT.



      (3)   ASSOCIATE.



   (B)   Suspected or questionable cases of tuberculosis shall submit
to re-examination at intervals as requested by the District Health
Commissioner or the Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller.  Such
examination shall include a tuberculin skin test or x-ray examination of the
chest and bacteriological examination of the sputum or other discharge, as
indicated by the District Health Commissioner or the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller.



   (C)   All members of a household where a case of communicable
tuberculosis exists or has recently existed shall be examined for
communicable tuberculosis at such intervals as may be designated by the
District Health Commissioner or Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller. 
Such examination shall include x-ray, skin test, and laboratory tests as may
be indicated.



   (D)   Patients with active or communicable tuberculosis shall be
examined at intervals of not more than 6 months duration or such other
intervals as may be required by the District Health Commissioner or the
Hamilton County Tuberculosis Controller.  Such examinations shall include
x-ray examination of the chest or bacteriological examination of the sputum,
secretions, excretions, or other discharge.  Reports of such examination
shall be filed with the District Health Commissioner or the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller on request.



('80 Code, § 92.12) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.13  PROVIDING FOR EXAMINATION OF EMPLOYEES OF HOSPITALS, MATERNITY
HOMES, INFANT HOMES, NURSING HOMES, NURSERY SCHOOLS AND CHILD DAY CARE
CENTERS, AND BABY-SITTING SERVICES.



   The individual in charge of any of the above named institutions or
services shall insure that part of the pre-employment evaluation of all
personnel shall include a tuberculin skin test (Mantoux 5 T.U. preferred)
unless the individual to be tested is a known positive reactor in which case
an x-ray shall suffice.  All positive reactors shall be x-rayed to rule out
active disease.  Subsequent examinations to exclude tuberculous disease
shall be to tuberculin skin test all negative reactors.  All positive
reactors shall have a chest x-ray. Such re- examination shall be at intervals
determined by the District Health Commissioner or the Hamilton County
Tuberculosis Controller.



('80 Code, § 92.13) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)  Penalty, see § 96.99



§ 96.14  REGULATION FOR TESTING SCHOOL CHILDREN FOR TUBERCULOSIS.



   The following regulations are established as screening regulations for
tuberculosis control for the schools of Indian Hill:



   (A)   Minimum standards for screening.



      (1)   Negative reactors.  No longer than three years between
screening.



      (2)   Positive reactors.  (With one year prophylactic
therapy) Three years between screening.



      (3)   Positive reactors.  (Less than one year prophylactic
therapy) No longer than one year between screening.



   (B)   1976-1977 school year.



      (1)   Students.  All lst and 7th grade students.  (A school
may be waived if there have been no new positive reactors in the preceding
three years.  Screening would resume the following year.)



      (2)   Personnel.  Every employee (including volunteers) must
be screened during 1976-1977 school year.



         (a)   Every employee must have a tuberculin test unless
they are a known positive reactor.



         (b)   All positive reactors must present evidence of
having a chest x-ray revealing the absence of active clinical tuberculosis.



         (c)   Personnel currently employed must present evidence
of compliance within 30 days after the scheduled testing for that school. 
New employees must comply within 90 days before the first work day.



         (d)   A certification card will be given each employee
from the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis Control which should be
kept and presented the following year if waiver is indicated.



         (e)   Certification cards will be given automatically to
those individuals tested by the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis
Control in the schools or in their clinical facilities.



         (f)   Personnel screened by their private physicians or
other sources must submit to the Hamilton County Department of Tuberculosis
Control documented evidence of the date and type of skin test and the result;
or if a positive reactor, the date and result of a chest x- ray.  (Neither
date to be before June 1 of that school year.)  The Department of
Tuberculosis Control will then issue a certification card.  A card will be
given in similar fashion to those presenting documented evidence of having
had aequate prophylaxis.



   (C)   1977-1978 school year.  Personnel in schools which had 100%
compliance in 1976- 1977 school year will be waived according to the
following schedule, between screening.



      (1)   Negative reactors         3 years



      (2)   Positive reactors (with       3 years



         adequate chemotherapy)



      (3)   Positive reactors (without    Annually



         adequate chemotherapy)



('80 Code, § 92.14) (Ord. 12-76, passed 4-26-76)



§ 96.99  PENALTY.



   Any person failing to comply with this chapter shall be deemed guilty
of a misdemeanor and subject to penalties provided in R.C. § 3709.99.



('80 Code, § 92.99) (Ord. 3-81, passed 3-30-81)

CHAPTER 110:  ADVERTISING

§ 110.01  POSTING OF PLACARDS AND OTHER BILLS, UNLAWFUL.



   Except as provided in § 155.06:



   (A)   It shall be unlawful to post up, affix, or cause to be posted
up or affixed any bill, placard or notice, either written or printed, upon
fences, trees, walls, poles, buildings, or upon any part of any property in
the village, without the previous consent of the occupants of the property,
or, if there be no occupants, without previous consent of the owners.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful to post up, affix, or cause to be posted
up or affixed any bill, placard, or notice, either written or printed, in or
upon any public right-of-way, or roadway, or upon any building or property
belonging to the village. 



('80 Code, § 91.25) (Ord. 34-44, passed 12-19-44)  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.02  DUTY OF POLICE DEPARTMENT.



   The Police Department is authorized to remove and destroy any such
bill, placard, or notice, which has been posted up or affixed in violation of
§ 110.01. 



('80 Code, § 91.26) (Ord. 34-44, passed 12-19-44)



§ 110.03  EXCEPTIONS.



   The provisions of § 110.01 shall not apply to public notices posted or
affixed according to the law of the State of Ohio, or any subdivision thereof.



('80 Code, § 91.27) (Ord. 34-44, passed 12-19-44)



§ 110.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating the terms of § 110.01 shall be fined for each and
every offense not more than $25.



('80 Code, § 91.99(G))

Ord. No.      Date         Description
